description:
Love this place so much.  The staff are easy going/friendly.  The rare beef salad is incredible, so much flavor and crunch and herbs.    The BBQ chicken was juicy/tender as well.  I'd be here every week if I lived closer

Yum Yum YUm
author: Mandy H.

description:
*Cash only

Serious pho craving late night after drinking earlier in the day. There weren't too many options available after 10pm so we opted for My Canh.

The restaurant is really small with only about 6-8 tables inside and pretty run down. Ordered four bowls of pho and a side order of egg rolls which totaled to about $45 before tip. The prices are reasonable considering it is in the city but the quality was below average. 

As other reviewers have mentioned, this is more of a drunchies spot so don't expect great service or food.
author: Amy P.

description:
I support small businesses and restaurants that sort of meet the definition of a hole in the wall. But, this restaurant was not a fit for me.

I ordered the #23 - Special noodle soup, which is basically the typical combination pho with the rare steak, meatball, tripe, tendon, etc. I thought the broth was a bit too salty and had an odd aftertaste to it. The bean sprouts they gave me was a bit old & yellow and the lime was all dried up like it was cut open hours ago. The noodles and the meat were fine, but the old condiments kind of turned me off.

I like how they're open late (till 2 AM) and they cater to the late night crowd. But if it's not too late yet in Chinatown, I'd recommend going to another place for pho.
author: Victor L.

description:
I came here with a friend during a weekday evening since we were feeling like getting pho and were in the neighborhood. When we walked in, it was pretty empty and we took a seat near the back. I defaulted to the special noodle soup and glanced at the wall while we were waiting for the staff to take our orders. When we saw a picture of the beef carpaccio on the wall, we asked the staff how much it was since it wasn't on the menu. She seemed to hesitate a little before saying that it was $17. We decided to pass on that and my friend felt that she was making up the price on the spot. 

Our orders came out within five minutes, which was in my opinion pretty fast for pho. The special noodle soup came with the side of bean sprouts, basil leaves and a slice of lime. Upon closer inspection of the vegetables and the lime, it seems that they weren't fresh. The lime especially seemed pretty dried up. Basil leaves were slightly frayed with a shade of black. The pho was okay though, and I don't have much to say about it other than it wasn't bad. It was still pretty filling. All in all, it was alright.

When we got the check, the staff loomed over us and it felt pretty awkward that she was standing over us while we were paying. I felt a bit annoyed by that since this was the first time that has happened to me and it was in poor taste in my opinion. If it was just the pho, I probably would have given this place a four. However, I'm taking off a star because of the vegetables and the other warning signs we spotted. Overall, would recommend this only if the other pho places in Chinatown are closed.
author: Nelson X.

description:
What a gem - we found a hole in a wall that opens late at night meat our hotel.  The place is disorganized and cluttered.

The restaurant is small and cluttered with about 8 to 10 tables.  We were lucky to be seated immediately late night for a party of 5.  

Want drinks?  You will have to get your own drinks i.e. water and soda.  There is a a refrigerator in the back.  They do serve hot tea.  

Foodwise, we had the pho dac biet which was too salty for my liking.  The saltiness overpower any pho flavorings.  We had the banh canh cua (Vietnamese crab udon) which was really good!  The flavoring and broth was on point!  We also had the banh xeo (Vietnamese savory crepe).  The banh xeo was thin and flaky.  I love eating these spring roll style which you can request.  

I would definitely come back here to fulfill my late night cravings.  Especially for the banh xeo.
author: Felisha L.

description:
Eat before dash and pay cash

If you have ever seen any shady places that only takes cash because they don't want to pay taxes, this is the place. However, let skip over what ever reason behind that, I love their banh canh ("udon", for anyone who doesn't culturally appreciate). 

A very plus point for this very shady place is that the restroom is rather clean. I'm usually an anti-unisex restroom person because I disgust that guys don't aim right and splash all over the toilet seats (unless the restroom has a female and male stall). But seriously, although the restroom here is small, it is so clean. Unlike the Burger King I went to previously downtown near Macy's at Union Square. 

Ok, let's go to the main point. The food. Banh canh here has the distinct Vietnamese orange color! I love that! It is not food coloring fyi, but annatto. Each bowl comes with a part of a crab. I honestly prefer that they crash the crabshell open instead of me chewing on it. 

The hot bowl of soup warms hearts in the cold of SF. Come and try.
author: Trinny T.

description:
Great late night eats at a budget! 

Don't expect anything here is except a hot bowl of noodle soup and minimal service. The prices are low but it's perfect after a night of drinking. 

Cash only!
author: Lindsay C.

description:
Ugh. This is my lowest rating to date for a restaurant.

This place was a hard 'meh' for me.

First of all, yes, the place is extremely dingy, but I was willing to overlook that because 1) so are all the other places surrounding it and 2) there are some dingy restaurants everywhere that are absolute diamonds in the rough. 

My Canh is not one of them. I ordered the crab and tomato soup and it was like vaguely crabby water. Imagine like a hot, crab flavored La Croix. The seafood mush on top was unappetizing and everything else was just too unmemorable to even describe. The fried wontons were like 98% fried air and 2% whatever meat mush was at the very bottom. Both dishes were edible, but not much more. 

Here's the thing though--this is definitely a drunk food restaurant. First, it's probably the cheapest food I've ever had (yes, cheaper than McDonalds) and it comes quickly. It's open until 2 am and I'd probably think it were good if it was 1:30 and I'd had 10 shots of tequila throughout the night. But barring that scenario, I wouldn't come here. I'd much rather pay more and have better food. 

Overall, I've been pleasantly surprised by most of the dirty, hole in the wall places I've been to in SF (even convenience stores in Bayview). But this was not one of those cases. Not even close.
author: Claire C.

description: Um, only the best Bo Tai Chanh (beef carpaccio) in town! The soups are standard but I really come here for the raw beef. Open late night for clubbers and bar crawlers, cash only!
author: Joyce Z.

description:
My Canh is a small Vietnamese restaurant that is located on the edge of Chinatown near North Beach/Russian Hill. It is one of three restaurants on the same block that are open till 2 am (the other two being Sam's and Panuchos). I tried it out a couple of days ago when wanting something late at night. It is a pretty run-down place that definitely needs a good scrubbing but I guess most places in Chinatown would fall under this category.

I decided to get the Chicken with lemongrass over rice ($7.95) to-go. Ordering was straight forward without issues and after ordering I waited for about 10 minutes at one of the tables while the cook rustled up my dish and I was on my way.

I got a small size container with a lot of rice and a small amount of chicken fried with lemongrass and I mean a tiny amount. It obviously lacked the intense taste of lemongrass but I could pick up some lemongrass taste if I concentrated hard. The rice also could have been much better, it was at best passable. Overall pretty average.

Price wise it was pretty cheap with cost being under $10 for a fresh cooked meal. Obviously, it was cash only. The quantity of protein in this dish was enough for a late-night snack but it would be too little for a regular meal. I have to give them props for being open late and being cheap but that is balanced out by the dirty run-down nature of the place and the small serving size, so I'm going to have to go with an A-OK grade at-best.
author: Ahmad J.

description:
My Canh is located on the fringes of Chinatown /North Beach border. 

I strolled in recently and plopped myself down for a bowl of mixed pho. 

Service was friendly and a bowl of piping hot pho came out. The prices here are a little bit cheaper than the competitors however the pho itself I would say was a little bit below average in terms of broth taste and also the ingredients didn't appear to be as fresh. 

The venue itself is a little bit older to be generous but I guess with the late hours and price point it has it's fans. 

The world needs a SF Bay Area Pho Rankings...so I'm here to provide my humble list/rankings.

Ranking explained:  #1 (listed at the top)  is my favorite/ #?  (listed at the bottom) is my least favorite. Check out my latest reviews for my latest up to date Rankings. 

When I look at reviews sometimes just want to know where to go or how a user compares one venue against another to see if we have similar tastes. If you're curious, I have rankings for Boba, Bakeries and Ramen , Chicken and Waffles as well (random right?)  Follow my profile to see my most recent reviews.  I hope I can be helpful since so many Yelpers have helped me discover new places. 
Rod's Pho Rankings for SF Bay Area:
1 Ly's Vietnamese Cuisine
2 Turtle Tower
3 Rang Dong Restaurant
4 Golden Star Vietnamese Restaurant
5 Pho Huynh Hiep 2 - Kevin's Noodle House
6 R&D Café
7 Mai's Kitchen
8 Noodles Pho Me
9 Chopsticks Pho & Grill
10 Rice and Spoon Vietnamese Cuisine
11 Pho Tan Hoa
12 Pho VN Vietnamese Restaruant
13 Pho 2000
14 Pho Vi Hoa
15 Bistro Viet House
16 Golden Flower
17 Pho Ty II
18 Pho Pasteur
19    My Canh
20 Kim Huong
21 Pho 99
author: Rod M.

description:
I came here on a Friday night (Chinese new year) so almost everything in Chinatown was closed :( After a few drinks in the North beach area with my friends, we decided to come here - open late night AND on CNY = win! Unfortunately, it is cash only, but luckily my bf has Wells Fargo and it's conveniently located across the street :) 

We ordered the Bo Tai Chanh (Vietnamese Beef Carpaccio), Banh Canh Cua (Vietnamese Crab Soup w/ Udon Noodles) - the two dishes they're known for and also a beef ball and tripe pho (this isn't on the menu, but I just asked if they can do this and they were ok with it) YAY! :) 

I've never had beef carpaccio and was veryy iffy on trying it, but they persuaded me, and it was actually pretty good! With sauce and everything mixed with it, it did not taste raw or beefy/bloody at all! Definitely better than I expected. The crab udon noodle soup was also very tasty as well. The broth is a little thicker than your usual pho and was very flavorful. The beefball and tripe pho was very tasy as well. The broth did not need hoisin sauce or siracha to help its taste either!  

This place is not the cleanest, but what do you expect in Chinatown and at a cash only place open late at night? Overall, I will definitely come back again if I'm in the area and definitely recommend it if you're looking for a late night meal aka drunchies =)
author: Bailey L.

description:
CASH ONLY.

Low key upset that I've lived in SF for TWO WHOLE YEARS and I've never heard of this place.

My brother, a non-SF resident, recommended this spot because it's his go-to after a night out. (Wait, what? You go out in SF and I don't get an invite?...)

The Banh Canh Cua is beyond this world. They use REAL CRAB in their noodle soup! The broth is thick (*round of applause for the inventor of corn starch*) and tasty. The noodles aren't mushy and perfect for banh canh. There's even a couple pieces of pork blood! Heaven, I tell ya.

One of those places where I automatically wipe down the utensils without thinking. Not much to look at inside, but why would you need to? The food is spectacular. Can't wait to evangelize this spot to everyone I know.

Tip: Cash only, but there's a Wells Fargo ATM across the street and it's very central to North Beach bars.
author: Vee B.

description: This little place has become one of my go to spots in San Francisco for pho.  Just as a warning it's cash only and the place is super small.
author: Ched C.

description:
TL;DR looks can be deceiving, their pho is great!

My Canh has the typical janky Chinatown restaurant vibe. Service is also typical, they take your order and give you your food, nothing more nothing less. They have a solid menu of noodle and rice dishes. They look pretty run down on the outside, but the food is good (and cheap)!
author: Sophia L.

description:
Look.
There are certain constants in life...

Like North Beach night life & the drunk munchies.

Not really any way of getting around it, unless you are very, very good, & skip the sauce.  

But, it is inevitable.  Eventually you will do a girls night, w nothing but the best intentions...

& there's a good chance that you'll end up here (or Sam's) at 2am.

If you're a hardcore pho person, admittedly this is hardly the best bowl you're going to get in the city.  But hey, not everyone can be Tom Brady, you know what I mean?  

And pho is SOOO good on a chilly SF night!  The fresh cilantro, the crushed peanuts...the vermicelli noodles, & the broth that's seemingly going to save your life.  Do it right & order egg rolls...soak it all up.

Vietnam Restaurant was my favorite on this block, but since they're gone now, welcome to your new super divey late night Vietnamese default spot.

Another venue that, if you haven't hit @ 2:00 am, then you haven't done North Beach proper.

Respect.

3 stars.
author: Veronica M.

description:
Great hole in the wall that was introduced to me by a friend years ago. I've only ever ordered the crab noodle soup and the beef carpaccio. I didn't order the carpaccio this time but I remember it being the best ever - super thin and flavorful.

I ordered the crab noodle soup (banh canh cau) this time and my craving was satisfied. Although, I'll admit that it wasn't as flavorful as I remembered, it's still one of the best crab noodle soup I've ever had. The soup is nice and thick and I love the added flavor of the fried onions. There are precracked crab claws and a body piece, which you have to chew though yourself (not a big deal for me). I had some meat stuck to the inside claw shell. There are also pieces of pigs blood, which you can order without if you're not a fan. They also give you hot sauce and lime wedge on the side.

One important note, they take CASH ONLY.
author: Carmen C.

description:
This place is located on the far reaches of Chinatown near North Beach/Russian Hill. The place was pretty small but there were a good number of tables and I was seated and eating quite quickly. It's not the nicest looking of places but the food was decently priced.

Had the Pork Chop with Rice, with Egg on Top, and the food was okay. Total was around $11 with tax. The pork chop tasted a little plain, and could have been seasoned a bit better. The egg was well made, and the dipping sauce was just okay.

Overall not amazing, but not terribly bad either.
author: Tyler T.

description:
This place was the only Pho place open after 1 AM on Sunday. Though the pho wasn't the best that I've ever had, it was definitely a solid meal. I appreciate how they cater to the late night crew. The service was quick because we were the only ones in the restaurant. There is definitely room for improvement here, as it isn't the nicest looking restaurant. However, the pho is great for a late night snack. 

I would definitely recommend this place for those late night cravings!
author: Darrell T.

description: Tonight I find myself at My Cahn, as I have many times over the past 20 years. This is where I first experienced pho, when a big bowl ran you $4 and change. My Asian girlfriends prefer the crab and pigs blood soup, but I keep it simple, stating "fuh-tai" as I stroll in. Not the best pho in town, but the best for the money. Ah, there's my bowl now.
author: Nick C.

description:
I've been dying to try this place ever since my friend told me about having a religious experience over the crab udon for a post-clubbing midnight snack. Finally got the chance to swing by when my sister and I decided to do a Pokéraid/Fat Fun Day adventure last Saturday.

Rating Breakdown:
2/2 Stars for Taste --
My sister and I each got a bowl of crab udon because we have no self-control. The chewy texture of the noodles in the thick, almost gravy-like soup....MM. So good. We were there in the afternoon, so i can only imagine how much more amazing this would be if I were half-drunk at 1AM. There were assorted pieces of pork belly and chunks of pork blood, as well as whole pieces of crab. My sister and I actually got too lazy to eat the crab...I know, we are trash.

We came for the noodles but the star of the show was definitely the bo tai chanh, which is the Vietnamese version of beef carpaccio. The tender, rare slices of beef are marinating in a tangy fish sauce/lime juice then topped with generous portions of chopped basil, fried shallots, crushed peanuts, and pickled onions. I was drinking that marinade. So fresh. So good. Perfect for a hot day. 

0.5/1 Stars for Price -- 
The crab udon and the bo tai chanh are off menu, so my sister and I had no idea how much it cost when we ordered them. We unexpectedly spent around $50 on two bowls of noodles and an appetizer. The $20 beef carpaccio was definitely worth it for me, but I don't know if I would pay $15 again for those noodles again.

0.5/1 Stars for Customer Service --
It's a hole in the wall Asian place so expect run of the mill Asian service. They brought tea, they brought the food, they brought the bill. 

Bonus star because I would come back for the bo tai chanh!

TL;DR: BEEF CARPACCIO YUM. Crab udon = good but pricy drunk food -- open late (2AM). Cash only.
author: Abby W.

description:
Long overdue rating! 
Love their Banh Canh Cua, flavorful and lots of crabmeat with pork meat. Soup is thick with udon like noodles. 

Raw beef with lemon (Bo Tai Chanh) was also good. Sweet and sour.

Though this place does not look appealing on in the inside, their banh canh is bomb and I would recommend this place.
author: Lynn T.

description:
*** CASH ONLY ***

Came here with a party of 5 on a Tuesday night around 8pm. Parking is kinda tough around this area but we found some street parking & walked 2 blocks. We were seated as soon as we entered. A lady brought us a pot of tea; think it was green tea. Tidy, casual restaurant with 9 tables (I counted while I was waiting for the food lol). My party & I ordered... 

5 Crab Noodle Soups - $9.75/each
1 Raw Beef Salad - $5.95
1 canned Grass Jelly Drink - $2.00 

The soup contained udon noodles, crab meat (we asked for it to be de-shelled), thinly sliced chicken, pork blood, green onions & fried garlic. It was really good & had the perfect thickness. We asked for extra green onions (no extra charge). The raw beef salad was very tasty also & I rarely eat raw food. Lol. Thinly sliced beef combined with white onions, lettuce, fried garlic, grounded peanuts & like this chili, lime fish sauce. Nice waitresses. Fast service. Best crab noodle soup I've had to date!
author: Karen L.

description:
This place was bomb!!! It was my first time trying banh canh cua and nom nom nom it was delicious. Thick crab soup with thick noodles that has a burst of flavor. Comfort food at its finest. 

MUST TRY: 
- Banh canh (crab noodle soup) $15.95
- Bo Tai chanh (beef carpaccio) $7.95

Even their eggs rolls were so good too! Fried egg rolls with fish sauce. Yummm. 

Cons: 
- parking SUCKS. Circled around for about 15 minutes, parked a bit far so another 10. But I'd say the banh canh was worth it 
- bit surprised by the price even in this hole in the wall restaurant. Granted it's crab, but I didn't think it would be about $16. 

I'd definitely come back here, especially for late night knowing it closes at 2am. But I'd like to try other spots that would be closer, cheaper, or has more parking.
author: Raquel Y.

description: Been coming here almost 10 years . This my go to place after the club ,,open late till 3am hands down to the shrimp fried rice, crab noodles soup and the grilled  pork chop!! Always support independent business I tip more cuz the food is waaaay is to cheap for the bay standards.  Support FAMILY BUSINESS!!! Love My Canh!!!
author: Alexandria K.

description: Been coming here once in awhile for consecutive years. Always hits the spot. My fav pho place in Chinatown!
author: Angelina W.

description:
If you're reading this? Answer those questions first, before trying this place out.

Are you Vietnamese? 
Yes? Well you'll hate this place.
No? Please don't let this place be the judge of our food/culture.

Restaurant is small, dirty and service is very rude. Though I'm Vietnamese, the ladies working there treat white customers better than they treated ALL the other Asians customers. Besides the fact that crab in the special was dead..

This place gets 3 stars because if you miss your family or crave banh canh, they do a okay job at it. You won't over pay and will leave with a feeling of content, if all you're looking for is to satisfy your craving.
author: Charley P.

description: The crab udon is amazing. They open late and have fast service. This place is small and the tables/ chairs are closely packed.
author: Pa H.

description: This place is disgusting. The only reason I forced myself to eat here is because it was late in the evening and I was really craving grilled meat. When I got my plate they served this ONE little piece of porkchop. I should've took a picture of it but I swear it's as small as the "PALM" of my hand. I had to use the hot tea to wipe the table down because I realized they weren't going to do it. The table was so dirty the white napkin turned orange. To top it off the food I ordered grilled pork chop with pork skin over fried egg was not good, they only take cash, the place is filthy and the people there are so rude.
author: Jojo C.

description:
Food: A few decent vegan and vegetarian options. I settled on tofu with broccoli. It was good, but not delicious. The tofu was tender and the spicy garlic sauce was a little too fatty and not salty enough for my taste. Portion sizes are generous for already cheap prices. My fiancé had beef chow fun and loved every bite. 

Ambiance: Typical hole in the wall type of place. Grungy, hot, and small. No A/C and open kitchen make this a spot to avoid on hot days. Cash only, so bring some paper if you want to get your grub on.

Service: Slow, distracted. I'm not sure if we went on a weird day, since other reviews dub this place as 'fast' but our visit was anything but. My fiancé asked for no vegetables in his food (we both have odd food preferences), but he was treated with bean sprouts and plentiful onions. 

Overall, three stars. I wouldn't go out of my way to go back, but I wouldn't avoid it either.
author: Shannon H.

description: Had f#14, Seafood Pho w/ Won Ton, served piping hot and it was very good. Came with tea in a glass and both were served quickly and politely.  They have 4 signs stating Cash Only.  The menu seems pretty extensive including Lunch and Dinner options.  I will be coming back b/c I really like Pho.
author: Jim I.

description:
All I was told was they had good Banh canh (udon)...after a long exceptionally cold day at the beach, yes we are those people; all I could think about was the crab udon. When we got there I'm trying to convince myself and the starving family it'll be okay since the place was SUPER SKETCHY; they say the best food comes from dives. 

We order....

YASSSSS! The most authentic crab soup & crab udon I have ever had! I finished my bowl and helped myself to my son's.(don't judge me s*#t was good!) 

You've been warned; it's a hole in the wall with mediocre service and great food! 

No pics because I was hungry and it was so goood!
author: Mama M.

description:
So so so good. Some of the best pho I've had in the bay. It's also really cheap and open late, so what else could you ask for. The service is simple and easy and did I mention the pho is amazing? 

I would highly recommend this to people looking for a delicious bowl of pho.
author: Megan M.

description:
Ordered: Fried Beef Sauteed in Lemon Grass w/ Rice Noodle
Received: Good food

If you are hemming and hawing between wanting meat, a salad or some noodles, why not combine all three and order the Fried Beef Sauteed in Lemon Grass w/ Rice Noodle?

Place is very hole-in-the-wall, and I didn't get sick from eating here. So all-in-all a good experience. I'll be back to try the Banh Canh Cua and Bo Tai Chanh. Protip: They're not on the menu, but are written on pieces of paper stuck to the wall.
author: Shuan W.

description: This place has the worst Pho I've ever had in a restaurant. The broth was extremely underwhelming and watery; the meat was sparse; there was no citrus with the basil and bean sprouts; the service was at best indifferent. You get what you pay for, I guess.
author: Charles W.

description:
Bad food and rude staff! Came here after a late night show. So the 1 star is for opening late but the rest is just down right horrible. 

I don't understand the hype about the crab soup. It was not even soup. It was thick like gelatin, not at all like soup. It was also pretty tasteless. 

The worst part was the slow and rude service. The waitress was ignoring us and rolled her eyes when we asked for togo boxes. 

The place is so dirty  I would never want to eat raw meat here.
author: Cindy W.

description: My favorite Banh Canh Cua! Have tried numerous places in SoCal but this one hits the belly more! The soup is thick and not watery, and there is real crabmeat on the claw! The kids liked the Bun Rieu too... it had the shrimp paste smell... yummy! Hole in the wall but worth the trip for us!
author: Elle W.

description:
I ordered the Crab Noodle Soup and it looks not good. 
The soup feels like melted jelly. The crab does not taste fresh. 
I just paid for the plate and left it uneaten. I did tried it and it was not good. 
I should not choose the picture advice on the restaurant. They are usually more expensive and unpopular.

Also, I wanted to be nice and pay for the food, but the waitress asked me why I didn't eat it. I told her I didn't like the taste. It was not fresh. She told me I don't know how to eat. Come on, I still paid for that sh!t and you insult my sense of taste?! You earned one star review for both your food and your treatment. 

I would not come here again.
author: Alberto W.

description: My lunch spot for work if I'm craving rice plate..I like the pork chop good flavors I wish I the portion was slightly larger but I guess I could get more add one..
author: jonathan h.

description: At first, I was going to give 2-star review solely for the Vietnamese Crab Udon (Banh Canh Cua). Then, I looked at the picture and tried to recall how it tasted, I realized a 1-star review would be more accurate. It's known to be a great place for late-night fix for for people who are munchy after clubbing or insomniacs that don't really care much about the quality of the food. All I tasted was (loaded) MSG and bad quality crab meat that were masked by the amount of alcohol in my body at the time I had it. I can also write another long review about the sanitation of this place which is a common thing at a lot of restaurants in SF Chinatown. Wonder how they are able to pass Restaurant and Food Inspection!
author: Jessie L.

description:
+.5 for service

My Canh is a Vietnamese restaurant in the north end of Chinatown, focusing on their speciality dish of banh canh cua (although they have their standard pho and other noodle dishes too). Given the fact it's their specialty, it only makes sense for me to order it for dinner.

I've had banh canh cua before in other places and have a good idea on what to expect. Given the fact SF is famous for their seafood, I also had high expectations for their crab. Unfortunately for $13, I felt their product fell a bit short. While their crab meat, broth, and portions were very good, I felt the noodles were overcooked as they broke apart too easily. I'm used to the kind of banh canh that's chewy, and unfortunately I didn't get that from this place.

Service was very good for an Asian restaurant; I actually felt I got very good treatment while eating here. Unfortunately it probably won't be a place I'll revisit again.

Cash only!
author: Calvin S.

description: A dirty hole in the wall that's been here longer than most of us have been alive. Don't expect a clean health inspection rating. Do expect fast service and good noodle soups. Avoid the grilled/BBQ meats (too dry). Fried spring rolls were on point.
author: Long C.

description:
I live in Chinatown but never visit this place before.
They open until 2pm which is great.
So tonight was pretty cold outside and I suddenly want to have some warm Asian food to comfort my Asian stomach.
Unfortunately it is kinda late I don't really have a lot of option. 
So, I walk in this store. first thing that I noticed was: their service was pretty good!
I order the largest pho on the menu, they send me the Pho in like 5 Minute.
It is good!you don't taste MSG(as an Asian I hate ppl put hella MSG In the food it just brings me headache)
The soup is goooooooooooood! By far the best pho I have.
5 stars all the way!
author: Emily H.

description:
Their crab udon is good, everything else is meh.

Growing up in the area, I've passed by this place more times than I can remember. It looked like any other hole-in-the-wall restaurant located in Chinatown and never really intrigued me. After an eventful night in the North Beach area, I was surprised to find this spot open and decided to give it a try.

I've had their pho and bun bo hue with both being mediocre at best. Even being slightly inebriated and famished didn't make those dishes palatable. However, a friend raved about their crab udon and highly recommended it. Reluctantly, I found myself here recently after a night in the area and decided to give it another try. I could not find their crab udon on the menu, but the staff knew exactly what I meant when I ordered it. What I received was a very pleasant surprise: a bowl of udon noodles, crab, pork, and pork blood. However, the highlight of this meal was the delicious broth. It had the same viscosity of eggflower or hot and sour soup but the flavors were complex and full of umami goodness. I don't always drink the soup but this was too good to waste.

If this review was only for the crab udon, My Canh would get a solid 4 in my book. While delicious, it was a small bowl and there wasn't much. Also, unlisted was the price, which was 13 before tax and can come at a surprise, especially for those who only carry cards (cash only here). In my opinion, I would have excluded the crab and put more of everything else, especially that broth. Since this review is for the restaurant and not just one item, it's a 3 because everything else I've tried is a 1 or 2 (not good even when drunk). I've read good things about their beef carpaccio, so I may try that if I'm in the area again. To summarize: the only thing they should serve is their crab udon.
author: Philip W.

description:
Oh myyyyy god. The food was good. The Pho was good. The spring rolls were bitter? 

The bathroom however was literally COVERED IN SHIT COLORED WATER. The water went all the way into the kitchen and there were flies everywhere. I couldn't breather when I went to the back of the store. 

I was so grossed out I immediately left. Nasty.
author: Cassandra C.

description: Authentic Vietnamese banh canh cua (crab udon noodle soup)  & bo tai chanh (beef carpaccio) is to die for here! The portions were huge and it was packed with a lot of flavors, so yummy! Parking was a pain and it's cash only.
author: Thuy N.

description:
After watching "Me Before You Movie" with close friends. I was super hungry and had a craving for some PHO! - I appreciate restaurants that are open late. 

We went in to My Canh and there were many people enjoying their food.
I ordered beef pho and shrimp fried rice. less than a min the pho came out.

The beef and the soup really hit the spot. I didn't want to sleep drive so ordered Vietnamese coffee to-go! The staff were super attentive and quick.

Great for late night cravings!!!

FYI- They only take cash!
author: Christina L.

description:
Party people of SF knows this place well. 

After a night of drinking in north beach. Most will head here for some pho to pre cure the next day hang over. 

It can get pretty crowded if you don't beat the after party group. 

I think they have the best Vietnamese style beef carpaccio in the city. I'm usually a few drinks in so don't hold me to the claim.
author: Lyman C.

description:
If you are debating between My Canh or Vietnam Restaurant for a good bowl of heartwarming Pho, I suggest you go with My Canh.

The broth tastes better and there's more meat in My Canh's pho bowls than Vietnam Restaurant. My Canh is also much more spacious and has more tables for its customers. 

CASH ONLY
author: Philip M.

description: I had the munchies around midnight on a Sunday, and was desperate for some good Asian food. Found this place on yelp and was not disappointed. Yes it seems like a sketchy part of town and its appearance makes you question the health code, but it's great late night food. My bf and I each had pho. It came out rather quickly. The food was great. We even ordered a beef noodle dish to go, and it was amazing. It caters to the late night crowd of loud girls, and lonely old men. Despite all of that, im glad they were open to take us in.
author: Toni Rose J.

description:
Food is bombtastic! I had the Seafood Pho which was fresh, quick, and hearty! :p

Cleanliness is another story...one word FLYS. I had to result in not using any of the condiments due to a hoard of flys grazing over them.
author: Christine V.

description:
Super awesome, sweet, courteous waitress. I assume her family owns the place as she was very attentive! 

Good real food cooked to order. We had hotpot and hofun. Delicious!!
author: Julie Z.

description:
LATE NIGHT noodle soup cravings after a night on the town in SF? My Canh surely fulfills that appetite

---Crab noodle soup: (the dish to order according to my vietnamese friends) flavorful with chewy udon-like noodles!

luckily there was no wait when we came late at night but i do remember the restaurant was packed nevertheless
author: Jenny S.

description:
So far the best Bun Mang Vit (Duck salad rice noodles with Bamboo shoot) in the entire Bay Area for me.

Their Banh Canh Cua (Vietnamese Crab Udon) is also very good.

It's also fun to eat while listening to the kitchen ladies bitching with each other about non trivial matters in life in Vietnamese, since their kitchen is right next to the dining tables.

Downsides are it's so hard to find a parking spot here and cash only. I had to drive around 30 mins just to find a street parking. Probably will go to a valet parking for $4 /hr next time.
author: Tung D.

description: Horrible horrible.. service.. BUT prices are amazing and the banh can cua is insane. Will come back. Ask for the peeled crab.
author: Christopher N.

description:
It's not hard to find late night eats in the city! 

We had a craving for Vietnamese food after a concert so my friend recommend My Canh! I love hole in the wall places like My Canh. We had their eggrolls for appetizers which I really liked. Most of us ordered the Banh Canh Cua. It was my first time having this dish so I have nothing else to compare it to. To me it was pretty good! The broth was yummy, but I think I would've been more satisfied with their rice plates, lol!

Solid 3 Stars for opening late and serving good food! 

CASH ONLY THOUGH!
author: Glenn L.

description:
This place is amazing, affordable and delicious !! What more do you want ?!?

Highlights include the beef carpaccio, egg rolls, crab soup and jellyfish salad. Each dish is light, tasty and less than 9 bucks - holy wtf !?!?
  
I also had their beef chow fun and it was nice and tasty - well seasoned, served with broccoli and bok Choy. 

I cannot recommend this place enough!
author: Anthony N.

description:
Tolerable.

This is a cash-only place that serves a ton Vietnamese dishes, often late.  There's not a scintilla of fanciness here - the tables are simple, the kitchen is open, and the service is quick but terse. 

The food here is just okay.  I tried some pork and egg roll vermicelli, and while the noodles themselves were good, the pork was gamey and the egg rolls were completely inedible. 

I'd probably not go here again.
author: Kirk S.

description: Best Vietnamese bánh canh cua  ( crab or shrimp noodle soup ) restaurant  in town. We don't order some other foods cause we all craving for those noodle soups. Definitely will come back next time .  Be sure to bring some cash . CASH ONLY place.
author: Chelseas D.

description: They barely speak English here. The food was sub par. I noticed 2 people who came in after me were served first. When I asked for the bill I noticed they overcharged me, and then started yelling at me in Vietnamese when I called them out on it. Horrible business I don't recommend coming here.
author: AK _.

description:
Used to love coming here back in my clubbing days at Ruby Skye. I don't know if it's because I was sober this time but came back recently and it wasn't as good as I remembered. I ordered the Banh Canh Cua, the noodles were overly soft and the broth was plain. So disappointed. Definitely won't be returning in the future. 
Surprisingly the service was better than usual.....
author: Julie N.

description: Very good late night Vietnamese food in sf ... pork clay pot  bbq chicken over rice with fried egg over the meal very good.. Vietnamese egg rolls are very good ..place is  hole in wall ... with late night strippers eating there after work ... been coming here for 10 yrs
author: Frankie L.

description: Came here again and got the Bun Rieu again, still delicious, great drunk food! My boyfriend ordered the Banh Canh Cua aka Crab Udon Soup. SO good! The soup is thick and noodles were chewy, the crab was so tasty and fresh! Loved it! We had 7 people and the bill came to be $60, so cheap! Worth it!
author: Natalie L.

description: It's by far the best cheap and tastiest Vietnam food in Chinatown. It's open from 6am to 4 pm so it's great for the early birds and night owl. It's great if your on a budget and want great food. If you live in SF you must try!!!Cash only
author: Benjamin G.

description:
Hmmmm... the banh canh cua... 

So, my friends and I always come here after a night of clubbing, such a convenience that they open late (CASH ONLY) 

I really enjoy their banh can cua... but here's the catch. When I'm drunk, or tipsy or whatever, I swear it tasted like heavennnnn, but one time I was craving it soooo bad that I came during the day, and guys... it did not taste good at all!!! It tasted like ummm i don't know, toilet water? (No, I do not know what toilet water taste like) but something in that category. The chow fun was a no for me, drunk or sober, and the grilled chicken over rice was definitely a NO. The water... NO. Some places just have horrible tasting water and this happen to be one of the places. 

Anyways, I somehow always get talked into coming here when I'm not in my right state of mind. Do I recommend it? Ehhh, not really, but give it a try, maybe you'll like it.
author: Temmara S.

description: I've been wanting to try this place for quite some time now. So after the Troye Sivan concert we decided to go here since it was close by and was the only soupy place that was open late. When we got there, my first impression is that this place is going to be good since its a hole in the wall, mom and pop looking like restaurant. We all order the banh canh cua (vietnamese crab udon) expect for two of my friends, they got the rice plate and pho dac biet instead. We also ordered some egg rolls to share. The egg rolls had too much taro and I did not like the wrap they use. The banh canh was average. Besides the pieces of real crab (which btw was sweet and meaty), the broth and the sliced pork were the biggest letdown. Service was friendly and food came out fairly quick.
author: Judy V.

description: Open late which is great. Bang can cua is a must ! can get a little messy so don't wear a shirt you love because the broth will definitely stain.
author: Sierra V.

description: Although I'm not Vietnamese, I can definitely sense the authenticity here. The workers here are pretty attentive and their bun rieu here is delicious! This place takes cash only!
author: Jennifer Z.

description:
Small hole in the wall restaurant. The restaurant is small with a few tables. It opens late, therefore it is convenient! Whenever I come to this restaurant, I order their Banh Canh Cua, the consistency is good and it is very delicious.

I have tried other dishes and I remember them to be quite delicious too. Do not expect a restaurant with ambiance and nice decor. This is a restaurant that needs so maintenance because it is a run down restaurant, but the food delicious to care. 

They are famous for their Banh Canh Cua, which is a vietnamese crab udon. You can order it with shell or peeled. 

Their feef carpaccio is also very good. I recommend this restaurant since it is convenient, they open late and also the taste of their food is good.
author: Rogelio Q.

description: Not sure about the sanitation in the place. Tables and utensils are as sticky as you would expect in a Chinese Vietnamese restaurant in Chinatown. Service is also as you would expect - not very good. But the food!!!  The delicious. If you have a strong stomach or want to have a good sampling of authentic Vietnamese food, this is more real than many places in the tenderloin and in San Jose.
author: Byron L.

description: Banh canh cua is a must try and so is their bo tai chanh! This place opens late until 3am.
author: Yennie L.

description:
Very bad and dirty place,  crab noodle is salty,  the guy made wrong my order crab noodle with shell ( my order no shell). Disappointed. 
Never go back .
author: Tien L.

description:
Came here at 2am after getting quite hammered and needing sustenance. Got myself the bun bo hue with udon noodles and it was DELISH. Could be the alcohol talking but it was so good every bite. We also got some beef carpaccio and while it didn't look the freshest, it was delicious still.There can be a wait so be prepared in case there are a lot of people. Most people come here for the crab noodle soup and I definitely recommend that as well.

Just remember it's cash only.
author: edward k.

description: Been here couple of times and the hole in the wall place taste like home cooked meals! I usually have the banh canh and it's always good. The raw beef is delish as well!
author: Lana T.

description:
Food is bland 1 star
Ordered a iced coffee but didn't arrived until our lunch is finished. Service 1 star. Will not come back.
author: Ken T.

description:
+ THE FOOD 
Their banh canh cua is all I ever need!! The broth is delicious and thick and there is plenty of noodles to keep you full. My favorite part about this place is that they use REAL crab in their noodle soup. They have at least 4 good chunks of crab legs or body, which I've never seen at any other restaurant. Their other dishes are not too bad either but I felt that the bun bo hue wasn't spicy enough.
author: Cindy C.

description: Pho was ok, waitresses are really rude. The throw the menus, got mad if you switch table and finally any other client who requested something for eye rolling from Amy of the three wicked witches of Chinatown. Avoid place
author: Xxxnoirxxx N.

description:
Chinatown, San Francisco, CA:  Wanted something filling and yet light.

Both Satisfying and generous portions. 

All the necessary accompanying ingredients present in my take out Rare Beef  and Beef Balls Pho order. Except napkins.  

The broth was tasty down to the last drop!

Service was friendly and quick.

Cash only.
author: Shal W.

description: Best hole in the wall find! They have the best crab noodle soup that I ever had! This place is really tiny and gets really packed at night since they open until two am.
author: Trang H.

description:
WOW really disappointed in this place.. After all the rants and reviews, I finally made it here, no, not after a long night of drinking as most others who frequent this place, Maybe had I been drunk I would have been able to enjoy the food? Lol yeah right.. I would have enjoyed this as much as Pho Kim Long in Vegas. Y'all been there? At least its cleaner than here.

We ordered the  Banh Canh Cua ( Crab noodle soup) , Bo Tai Chanh (Beef Carpaccio ) , and Bo Kho ( Beef Stew)

The Bo Tai Chanh had to be the star of the meal, and that doesn't say much. While there was flavor, it was disgustingly syrupy sweet, instead of slightly sweet, sour and fresh tasting as it should be.

The Banh Canh Cua tasted like sink water with no flavor at all. I was really shocked that people rant and rave about this here. Drank a little much before eating here?

The Bo Kho? How was it? I don't even know since they never even brought it out for me. They were pretty rude when we asked about it too, but you know what, it worked out in my favor since I didn't want to choke down any more garbage food, in that sticky chair without seat padding.
author: Sharon N.

description:
This is one of those places where I would not mind coming in to eat if it was late at night and I was craving some fast Vietnamese food after a night of clubbing or drinking at a bar nearby. 

While this place is passable, it is definitely not the best Viet food I've had. In my experience, the best non-homemade Vietnamese food tends to come from restaurants that specialize in one particular item. So if you see a menu that features pho, com tam, bun bo hue, and other random dishes on it, you should lower your expectations a bit.

The com bi suon cha I ordered was pretty passable. The pork chop was cooked, but looked otherwise. Veggies (lettuce pieces and cucumbers) were dry. Other than that, at least it was filling. 

At least it was my first time finding a place that serves com tam in SF. Unfortunately, it may be my last. I'll stick to getting my fix in San Jose.
author: Viet N.

description:
What is going on with this place?!  I swear the older woman who serves me is bipolar!  She's all friendly one day but then scowls the next time I see her.  The others seem to do the same thing - usually not very happy either.  I've been going there for about 4 years mainly because there are not very many places open late at night near where I live and they have decent food. I don't expect stellar service, but geez I could do without the feeling like I've done something wrong in their past lives right after getting the impression like they've become pleasant.

It's not because she forgot who I am because I tell her "the usual" and she knows what I mean, the #35 with fried eggs.  I usually smile or even wave when i interact.  I figure it's always good to be nice to those who handle your food.  I've noticed that it's not just me, they do that to most people who are not their visiting family member.  I hoped they would recognize my regularity and stop "wierding" me out with their mercurial service.

Perhaps it's just the way they are, but it's annoying enough to consider not going there anymore or for a long while (or try to find another place).  To make things less pleasant, the dish i usually order comes with grilled meat which keeps getting smaller and smaller in portion.  Perhaps they are telling me to stop being a customer?
author: Jake R.

description: Hole in the wall joint that good for late night food. Their special is the Banh Canh Cua. Flavors are super bland and fluctuates. Crab sometimes is fresh but not on most days. The rice plate seems like a winner. The beef in their Bo Tai Chanh is sliced too thick. Egg rolls have too much taro. Great spot for a tipsy palate but not if you're sober.
author: Julie L.

description:
Came here with Peter L after an evening of drinking. It was still super early, like 8:30pm, but soup sounded like a great idea. I'd been here years ago and had their Banh canh cua. All I remember was there were pieces of real crab and it was delicious! This time, we ordered:

18. Bun rieu: crab meat tomato with rice noodle soup ($6.95)
Make sure to ask for hot sauce and shrimp paste. Both made the soup more flavorful. And I always like a spicy kick.

22. Pho xe lua: extra large special noodle soup ($7.95)
This was okay. The soup could have had more flavor. Tasted better with lots of sriracha and hoisin sauce.

This last experience was okay. Even though I don't go out clubbing anymore, it's nice that My Canh is open late for a much needed post dancing meal. I would definitely come back to try the Bahn canh cua again. But I'll probably pass on the pho next time.
author: Elena N.

description:
Bun Bo Hue.

talking about Vietnamese noodle soup, this place has so many options to choose from not just Pho.
this place also has secret menu # 22 (not in the menu) which is Crab Soup.
my favorite is Bun Bo Hue (pork, chicken and pigs blood) in spicy hot broth.

open pretty late, good location, friendly people, cheap.

good stuff.
author: Rudy H.

description:
Get the #21: crab noodle soup!

Don't be scared by the "market price" next to the the banh canh cua menu listing. It was $12 (inclusive of tax) when I went earlier this week.

My dining companion, who LOVES this dish, said he has searched all of San Francisco and Los Angeles for something similar but this is the only restaurant that serves this delicious dish!

What's inside this hearty, big bowl of Vietnamese comfort?:
--Flavorful and hot, THICK broth (probably has MSG)
--Fat udon noodles (were a bit overcooked and slimy)
--Authentic squares of BLOOD cake (EEK! But actually it tasted like tofu to me. Still, it's not my thing)
--Lots and lots of fresh crab chunks! Be sure to order it removed from the shell, otherwise they will bring you the soup with the crab still inside the shells and that's not fun to disassemble!

Being a tiny Chinatown hole in the wall, service and the dining room were very minimal.

Worth trying at least once!
author: Peijean T.

description:
So it's Friday night, we had just finished happy hour and was looking for this well known crab noodle soup My Canh. Upon arriving to the restaurant, I noticed that it's located in the same area where the stripper clubs are at which is find with me. haha

The restaurant is fairly small, hole in the wall if you call it. Don't expect fine dining or remotely close to a 3 star decor. Just plain chair and table, somewhat like what you would find in chinatown. 

Food Ordered:  beef carpaccio, my favorite. Sauce was bursting with lot of favors, the fried onion was a nice touch. This was my favorite dish here!
Crab Noodle Soup (popular item) - it was good, but similar to the banh canh I have at other restaurants. the crab was a nice touch, but they didn't have a lot of crab meat.
Soup Mang - the broth was a bland, we had to add a lot of fish sauce for favors. Skip this item and not worth it. 

Overall, I would come back for the beef carpaccio for it was the best I've ever tasted. The prices are reasonable as well.
author: Lynnda T.

description:
Everytime I come to the City, I always stop at 3 places and My Canh is one of them. Yes the place is a little outdated but the food is the reason why i keep coming back. 

My go to:
Crab Bahn Canh - the broth, the way the noodles are cooked, and the crab pieces are perfectly balanced. I'm from the OC and I still prefer the Bahn Canh here

Beef Carpaccio - good balance of sweetness and citrus. 

iced coffe - nice and strong
author: Kacy J.

description:
Great late night fix! Came here after a night out and in need of some food to balance out the stomach.

Surprisingly, we didn't have to wait, but the place was crowded at 2am. Our group either got pho or bon bo hue and it was amazing. 

Will definitely come back for late night bites in the North Beach area.

Tip: This place is cash only.
author: Kerry D.

description:
Went to eat a late lunch and got the #23 (Pho Dac Biet) for $7.45 on 2/1/15.  The pho came with a lot of noodles and different kinds of meat.  It tasted decent, but I've had better pho since it wasn't that flavorful and I would have probably given it 2.5 stars for the food.  

I probably would have come by again if I was in the neighborhood, but when leaving, my sister noticed a small cockroach/bug on the floor.  That really turned me off... Now I know it's a hole-in-the-wall establishment and I don't expect it to be super clean or anything, but I won't be returning again, despite it having a decent health score of 83 because of the bug...  This made me drop down my rating to 1 star.
author: Gilda W.

description: A horrible way to throw your money out of window, $13 for the really small bowl of noodle soup and a tiny bit of shelled on blue crab. It's ridiculous. This soup is obviously made from soup base. No service at all and FYI cash only. stay away at all cost
author: Steve K.

description:
My Canh is my go-to/fave spot for some late night viet food. It opens til late night, it says 2 am on Yelp, but I've come passed that and was still seated. Especially after the club or bar, perfect way to end the night or sober up to get home!

They're a family owned pho restaurant that's open everyday almost all day. Mad props to the workers/owners for the long work hours.

It's right on Broadway right after the Stockton tunnel. All parking is metered street parking, but late night there's no worries. Just make sure you watch out for street cleaning. From experience, I've gotten a street cleaning ticket, $65 :(.

They're not very big, they have 2 larger round tables and others seat 4-5 people. The later you come, there's a chance you'll have to wait. Very popular late night on Fridays and Saturdays.

I always order their #21, Banh Canh Cua, crab noodle soup. Now I've definitely had better banh canh, but not in SF and especially not late night. The crab noodle soup is thick with udon noodles. It comes with coagulated pork blood, slices of pork, and pieces of dungeoness crab. The soup always comes out piping hot that's rich and tasty. Their udon is always cooked perfectly too. It's seasonal so it can range from $10-12 depending on the price of crab.

I've had their Bun Bo Hue, it's ok not really your traditional BBH. Their pho is average too.

Their fried imperial rolls Cha Gio are also really good. Their not tiny, they definitely don't jip you with some tiny a** pieces. They also come out freshly fried and piping hot. I couldn't even hold it with my hands. It's stuffed with filling with a nice light cripsy and flaky crust. Delicious. I've never had imperial rolls like theirs.

Their beef carpaccio (Bo Tai Chanh) is also pretty memorable. They make theirs slightly different, but it's delicious with a combination of flavors and textures in each bite. It is on the pricier end for an appetizer, if I remember correctly it's around $12.

Their price is average, but cash only. There's a few banks nearby like Chase and Wells Fargo.

I can almost guarantee you've had or will have better pho/viet food, but it's hard to find any that open this late.

Let's talk about their service. They seat you, take your order, bring out your food, and clean up. When you request for something, sometimes they ignore you. Most of the time they act like the ignore you but they bring it out shortly. Sometimes it takes more than one try to ask. Conclusion, their service is pretty bad. But surprise for a pho restaurant? not really. I can see that some people see them as rude. I've been accustomed to this kind of service from pho restaurants.
author: Stephanie L.

description: Really decent Vietnamese food for late night. The raw beef carpaccio is definitely a must! My only 2 issues are that they don't take credit (wth? It's 2017), and the place is kind of dilapidated compared to the other establishments close by. The place can use a little updating. Just saying..
author: Real R.

description: Banh canh cua is good. Service is interesting but the food was awesome. Small local joint for fast good food.
author: Phuong Rose S.

description: Kinda close to my work, so convenience. Banh canh cua is good and remember to bring cash on your pocket guys.
author: Kelly N.

description: Dirty dingy old school spot with good tasting food, open late, at a decent price. My asparagus and crab soup was good except for it didn't have any asparagus in it.
author: Andrew K.

description: Had to ask the waiter for everything--for bean sprouts and mint leaves for the pho--and for the dishes I already ordered 15 minutes ago. Also ordered a mongolian beef dish that came out to $11 and the size of the portion was a joke, with a few scraps of meat. (They seem to skimp on meat in general.) To add insult to injury, this place is cash only, but you can pay a few extra bucks in fees to withdraw from the Wells Fargo down the street. Aside from that, the flavor of the dishes was decent, so I'm giving this place 2 stars instead of 1.
author: Chris L.

description:
My sister loves this place and requested we drive all the way to sf for the bowl of udon crab noodle soup. To me it was just a regular bowl of soup. 

The bowl is not pleasing to the eye and we all know that you eat with your eyes first! First sip of the soup and it was very slimy! It's a lot thicker than what I'm used too and the slimy texture does not help. I think it lacked some seasoning because I had to squeeze in three pieces of lime. 

Looking at the bowl there was a lot of crab! Which is good for the price! But some of the crab tastes like plastic! So I basically discarded those and only ate the udon noodles. 

I added a star to this place because of how nice the owners were. It's a small restaurant that's opened till 2am! And they do this with a smile on their face. Can't complain about that!
author: Quyen H.

description:
eek, I reviewed the wrong place! I accidently reviewed Vietnam restaurant when it was really My Canh.

TLDR; Bland Bo Hue. 

HELLA bland Bun Bo Hue (how is that even possible?!)

Lemme explain.

I work in the area and often frequent Pho Vung Tau for my Vietnamese fix (see: hungover). After a quick HH while waiting for traffic to die down, we were feeling adventurous and wanting soup to wash down those tasty libations; A quick yelp search directed us here, and boy, were we in for it.

MTL opted for the Bun Cha Gio Thit Nuong with extra "homemade" fish sauce (nuc mam)..... for my fellow mi trang, it's basically a vermicelli noodle bowl with imperial rolls and slices of grilled pork. Honestly, it was pretty good.... But in my defense, it's hard to mess this up (especially with extra nuc mam (NADDA MEAN? FOSHO). Serving size was large and had a good amount of meat at $7.00.

However, I decided to be daring and get their bun bo hue considering MOST reviewers raved about their soup. BAD. I mean.... The noodles were good and the meat was plentiful, but the broth was just BLAND. Hell, when I want bun bo hue, I want one hand on the chopsticks and one hand on a napkin keeping sweat from dripping into my bowl. This honestly taste like water with noodles.... I've had nongshim bowl noodles for $1.29 that tastes better AND has more flavor. Hands down, the worst BBH I've ever had.

The interior was pretty run down (messy tables, flies everywhere, a string held the bathroom door open). While you'd expect this to be "standard Chinatown" ambiance, they should know that Pho Vung Tau around the corner is EXTREMELY clean with prompt service. Oh, did I mention better BBH!? Know your competition, people. At $20 out the door, it really wasn't that inexpensive for what it was.... But hey, at least it was a sobering ride home!

I don't think I'd give them another shot. People rave about their banh mi (lunch only, btw) but I'd personally take the walk down to little Paris on Stockton (who also has pho, btw) but if you don't wanna leave this corridor, hit up Pho Vung Tau.

Tip: Cash only
author: Ryan L.

description:
This review is solely base on one menu item: BÁNH CANH. I would not order anything from this restaurant except what was mentioned. The locals took us here and that what they ordered; I followed and Jackpot! The restaurant is really small with open kitchen; somewhat run down, the restroom was small and smelly. 
Bánh Canh was phenomenal. I normally hate to eat this dish but they have changed my mind completely. It has real chunk of Alaskan crab in there. Yum. Order this and be careful with the neighborhood at night, very dangerous area. On the way there, we saw one guy got beaten pretty bad and his two friends are calling the cops. Apparently, it was a robbery of some sort.
author: Phero V.

description: The crab udon noodle soup here is not as tasty as it used to be many years ago. The beef carpaccio is still good.
author: S T N.

description:
This place is pho-nominal. The bo tai chanh (viet beef carpaccio) is superb. Well balanced from the acidity of the fish sauce lemon marinade. The crushed peanuts and fried shallot on top added a nice texture to round the whole dish. 

We also ordered bun rieu, beef short ribs, and pho ga. All wonderful, authentic, home made viet dishes. I felt like I was at my mom's house when I was eating here. This is the place you take bae when you tryna impress them. I have found my new viet gem spot in the city.

Would highly recommend.
author: Nancy T.

description:
Probably the worst pho I've ever had. The egg rolls were not bad. Best part about this place is that it's open super late. 
Would not come here again, definitely not for pho.
author: Alex M.

description: I like how they have a lot of real crab in their banh canh. I really like the portion. The restaurant is like a hole in a wall kind of restaurant..pretty good and worth a try.
author: Nhung V.

description: I came to lunch for the first time with some people. I would usually not go to place like this for lunch but followed some people here. When I was eating my noodle soup, I found a dead fly floating in my soup. What could I do? I already ate the noodle soup and I had a little stomach problem afterward. I was so grossed out even today when I was reading people's reviews talked about flies everywhere and in bathroom with the shitty water at this place that I had to do this review. I guess it just my luck that I had flies in my food or drink for the second time in Chinatown.
author: Anonymous B.

description:
I found the pho to be so-so but the cha gio was fried to a perfect crispiness stuffed generously with minced pork. The perfect drunk food! 

Open til 3am on the weekends for all you late, late night "party" goers. (psst, strip club patrons!)
author: Janice C.

description:
YUP! That's right ! I give this place 5 stars and I'm not drunk, tipsy or whatever ... my fiancé and I got some late night pho last night to go and I just finished my chicken pho for breakfast and it was some of the best pho I've had in forever !  I got the chicken, my honey got the beef and he LOVED it! The beef was cut just right, not fatty at all and his broth was delicious with out any chiracha or hoisin sauce! 

The chicken was all white meat ( my fav) and it was nice and tender - not dry at all ! Which unfortunately I've had at other pho places and it just ruins the pho experience for me lol. 

Yea. This place is a "hole in the wall" , cash only ( which I personally don't have a problem with but those who live off plastic money prob hate "cash only" spots) 
There's really nothing I can say negative about this spot - it's open late also which is amazing !  I honestly do feel a little sorry for them due to the fact they are on the north beach side of broadway and they probably have to deal with drunken shenanigans probably every day ! 
Customer service was amazing as well. Everyone is so nice, welcoming and helpful  I will defiantly eat there again and recommend it to any pho lover out there !
author: Caroline M.

description: Love it! Waking up at 11pm, what else is better than a spicy soup base Special Pho? And the distilled coffee with condensed milk to top it up! And there is still a long queue right outside at 1am, I guess it is a proof of how great the food is!
author: Alan N.

description: Great pho broth. Super cheap for SF all in under $10 with tax and tip. Solid hole in the wall!
author: Alexander Z.

description:
I only tried one dish here but that's the only thing you'll ever need to order/ eat here. 

Ask for the RAW BEEF SALAD. It's not on the menu. Basically, it's a vietnamese style beef carpaccio. The beef is thinly sliced (like for pho) and is topped with vinegarized, thinly sliced onions, a little bit of lettuce, mint, garlic chips, fried onions and fish sauce. It's AMAZING. 

The raw beef salad is my new favorite food. SoOoOOo good!
author: Denise H.

description:
Cash only!!!

Every year I will come here at least once. Its a hole in the wall (should be cleaned a bit more therefore star deducted) and does not have nice decor or anything fancy but the food! Ohhhh MY...I always get my usual...

- Crab banh canh
- Beef carpaccio
- Viet ice coffee

And I will call it a day. Looks can be deceiving but never say no until you have tried it. Cannot and do not judge it's book by it's cover. Yummy!!!
author: Julie B C.

description:
I came here with a coworker for lunch and I mistakenly ordered something else instead of what I actually wanted. When I asked the lady at the front about changing the food she was very good about it. The server that brought the 2nd plate over gave me a dirty look. 

Food was ok but the customer service was super!
author: Sam Y.

description:
Their bun canh cua is very very tasty! as well as their bo tai chanh! I loveeee itt! I know that its probably pretty easy to make at home, since its not even cooked steak.. lol, but its just too much work...

When you can get bun canh, see if they have the crab that is already de-shelled. because i dont like using my hands to eat.

I am not going to lie tho, this place is definitely a hole in wall where drunk party goers end up at after a night of binge drinking :) not that I was one of them..
author: Judy W.

description: This place stinks! I ordered same dish three times, but they charge me different prices. 1st time 8.7 usd, second time 9 usd, and third time they asking 11 usd, what??? for same thing??? I told them they are wrong, but they took my dish away and ask me to leave. Excuse me? I was just try to reason, and they gave me such a bad attitude.This place should never exist. If you want a bad service who asks prices randomly, you can go, otherwise, stay away!
author: Cecilia X.

description:
My Canh is a Vietnamese dive diner in the heart of San Francisco's nightlife area, on Broadway on the edge of Italian North Beach, and Chinatown across the street. 

My Canh was also a famous restaurant in Saigon, Vietnam, long ago. I had been there as a child way back in the day before the war got very bad. It was a floating restaurant, floating on the Saigon river, and before and during the Vietnam war, was a popular place for Foreigners and Americans to dine. It was blown up in 1965 with two bombs, killing 42 people. 

This My Canh is a simple diner with a greasy feel, but with good tasting food. They are best known for perhaps 2 dishes, their Banh Canh Cua (Crab soup) and Bo Tai Chanh (Beef Carpaccio with lemons). But their Pho broth is deep, complex and delicious, and clear, with the flavor of beef embued over time, not with shortcuts. 

It is very good drunk food, being here near the nightlife, and it is hard to find a seat after midnight, when their rush hour begins. But it is also good sober food, despite the divey atmosphere. 

I have been here twice. Once, late at night with my good Vietnamese friend, who knows the staff and introduced me to the Bo Tai Chanh, which I had never had before. It was great for me, because I am a lover of beef carpaccio from way back when I used to eat it every time at a long defunct restaurant on Union street for Italian food. 

The other time was recently, when I was in the area and felt like Pho. The flavor was good, the Tai was typical, but the Gau was almost all fat. Tasty and tender fat, but I am used to the nice cuts of brisket from my local Pho hole.
author: Wanugee N.

description: Ordered pho, my  kho, and bo Tai chanh. All tasted terrible and there was a fat ass bug in my pho.
author: Julie T.

description: I like pho but coming in after midnight might have been a bad idea... Everything is not as fresh as it was when they open their doors probably.  My stomach didn't agree with all the food we had ( beef pho, glass noodle egg rolls and chicken pho ).  Yuck!
author: Kia M.

description:
Great place when you want to grab Pho during the late night hours!  I like how this place is opened late and is located near the bar scenes on Broadway!

They serve good and fast Pho!  Reasonably priced and fair portions.  Do order up their Banh Canh Cua - crab pieces with udon and a thick soup base!  It's unique and different from other pho styles!

Don't expect much from the service and decor.  Service is typical and the place is a bit rundown.  

Cash only!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
I had the crab noddles soup for $12. I would say the price is high if compare to others restaurant around but wait, it's totally worth your $12 bucks. The crab is soft, very flavorful, the noodles n the broth is cooked just right. For a late night done out to beat the SF windy, it's thumb up. The setting is typically Asian, Chinese restaurant style for Chinatown location. 
Well, the Chinatown area is mostly cash only so be prepared
author: Jane N.

description: The older waitress literally threw the menu on our table then walked away without any apologies.
author: Clover A.

description: Even though you'd think, you must be very hungry after hiking and that's why the food taste so good. I think not, I was here before and the food still tasted darn good. I had banh canh cua here just on july 2 and was here last year. The inside may be small but the food makes up for all of it.
author: Emily N.

description:
Okay, let me just start off by saying that if you're gonna come here, don't skimp yourself out of trying the Bo Tai Chanh (raw lime beef). It's a little expensive for a plate, but the $15 bucks really is worth it once you try it. 

Also, I'm a very very picky person when it comes to Banh Canh Cua because my family's recipe is simply the best I've ever had. However, this place definitely comes in second place. Their soup base was amazeballs and the noodles and crab were the perfect touch. I almost never finish my food and I finished the whole bowl here. 

I knocked off one star because the server there was really rude. Also, it was kind of a messy place. The bathroom is super scary too. 

*I also don't recommend trying the rice plates.
author: Serry T.

description:
I don't know what to say about this place... but, how did they get such high ratings?  My assumption is that they were probably once good when they first opened up.  As time progressed... things unfortunately probably went downhill for them.  Of course I can be wrong.  It could be any factor that caused the down turn.

Anyhow, I don't know if I ordered the right dish.  This place is beyond horrible.  No disrespect for the business, but My Canh is probably the worst Pho place I have ever been to.  My Pho Ga (chicken pho) was simply tasteless and I could probably count the number of shredded pieces of chicken in my bowl.  The small amounts of noodles in my bowl just simply didn't do it for me.  My broth was lukewarm and no flavor, the amount of shredded chicken given was probably less then the amount of meat equivalent to a drumstick, and my noodles wasn't even a handful.  It was basically a bowl of lukewarm msg soup that is plain and simple "horrible".

My friends had soup too. They ordered the regular pho which they said was also no good.  I don't know how we ended up in this place, but it's probably my first and last time coming here. 

My Canh itself is not attracted, and it's a hole in the wall.  They definitely need to work on their cleanliness.  The table was sticky, and the self service utensils was still dirty.  

We were so disappointed at this place that we went across the street to buy pizza to fill our stomachs after the Pho let down. 

My Canh, please please please improve in every aspect of your business.  Please serve better food, please clean the utensils better, please also have better service.  

One star, until there's a complete makeover!
author: ED L.

description: Love their crab noodles & raw beef salad here! It's a must! Usually super packed on Friday and Saturday nights after mid night. Get there earlier if you don't want to wait in line ;)
author: Pam Ela Y.

description:
They're open super late! We came in after drinking and we ordered a few things.

They were mad at us because a few of us were sharing, so not everyone ordered. Shit service.

Egg rolls were very oily but good for drunchies. But nothing amazing. Their pho is just okay. Great for late night but wouldn't ever come here otherwise.
author: Gina F.

description:
This is completely the best example of a "hidden gem", proof you do not have to be the fanciest to be the tastiest. 

Now, I can see this place getting horrible reviews because of the location and "grunge" ness but for Asians like me, we live by "the grungier the better"-- the "hole in the wall" feel. This applies most of the times..... Cept when you go home and realize it worked against your favor & you ended up getting good poisoning (Heh heh) 

Anyway I love giving in to my bougie ness with fancy restaurants but that does not mean I don't know a good taste when I try it! 

I saw someone post a picture of the bo tai canh (beef carpaccio) and knew I HAD to try it. I have not had this dish ever and although simple, it is so flavorful and yummy. I believe the lime "cooks" the meat. 

Hint-- it is not on the menu so just show then my picture or ask them for beef carpaccio if you don't speak Vietnamese! 

I also had the banh canh Cua which is this slimy soup with crab. It is do yummy! Just make sure you don't get it all over yourself because it is a B to get out! Very sticky! 

Overall- don't judge a book by it's cover and come in!
author: Christina R.

description:
For late nights - THIS IS THE PLACE TO EAT - (if you like Vietnamese Food)

I have been eating at this establishment for awhile now.  Every time I come back, it's always a good experience.  The owners now know me - and before they hand me the menu - they ask me if I want the usual which I do - and it's that simple!!

I recommend ordering their IMPERIAL ROLL.  It is crispy, fresh and they give you a large portion too!  Especially if you are like me who can devour it down in seconds!!

For soup - if you like PHO (a Vietnamese noodle soup, usually served with beef (ph bò) or chicken (ph gà).- I recommend the BEEF but they have SEAFOOD or COMBO too !  I usually order their BUN REIU (crab meat soup).  It is delicious.  You can request it with crab shell -- or no shell.

Another good dish is their FIVE SPICE PORK WITH EGGS.  They give you a big portion and you leave this place feeling your $10 per person  is well worth the money!  

They do get pack especially after 2:00 AM during weekends - which is the time when the bars closes!!  So plan ahead - and being in the city - dress accordingly because it can get very cold waiting outside!!  

PS -- Please note that this is a CASH ONLY dining and  if you eat here often enough like me - you get to know  the owners and the CHEFS - they are very, very nice. Next time you come back, strike up a conversation with them.
author: Edwin R.

description:
This place doesn't look like much from the outside.
But the food here is so good.
It's one of those San Francisco hole in the wall joints.
& this little gem is well worth trying it out.
We order beef chow mien. It was so flavorful and had a good ratio of meat to veggies. The noodles were fresh and not the traditional thick chow mien noodles, they we're skinnier, almost like a ramen. 
Will definitely return here soon.

&& they're open till 4am, whaaaat !!!
author: Nicky V.

description:
I don't get to come to SF that often, but when I do, I'm usually not around Chinatown so I don't get to come here as often as I'd like. So when my friend graduated, we decided to come here because she got out pretty late and the perfect opportunity to check this place out again!

When I first had their banh canh cua, I thought it was the most amazing thing like ever..that was 3 years ago and I couldn't wait to come back! This time around, the broth was so thick! Almost to the point of being gummy =(. It was good..but it wasn't anything great. My thought after eating it again was "I waited all this time for this??" Although the banh canh cua didn't wow me so much this time around, their bo tai chanh sure  did! If you don't mind eating pretty raw beef, GET THISSSS
author: Jen N.

description:
One of the best places I've ever been to for banh canh. It's the closest thing that's served in Vietnam while I was there. 

Service was quick and pleasant. Food came out right away.

The place was very small and gets packed very quickly. 

The soup was thick and hearty; very flavorful; but I like to add the lime juice and chili paste they bring out. 

There is also a secret item that is a "must try" if you go there. I'm not a big fan of raw foods like sushi; but they have this beef tar tar called "bo tai chanh" it's raw meat in slices covered in veggies and a vinegar/lime sauce. (Doesn't sound appetizing to me, but once I tried it... I was hooked) 

I'm defiantly coming back !!
author: Heather N.

description:
Several years ago, I went to this place for the first time and thought it was really good.

I recently went again and to my disappointment, it was not what I remembered it to be.  First off, the service is terrible. All of the ladies who work there are extremely rude and throw things on the table at you.  The facility definitely needs a deep cleaning and extreme makeover.  The food did not leave me satisfied. I ordered the banh canh tom cua and there were barely any pieces of shrimp/crab. The broth was lacking a lot of flavor. The others in my group ordered thit bo tai chanh that they said wasn't even good. I can't remember how much that dish ended up costing but my sister in law complained about how tiny the plate was for the price.  I will not be coming back here ever. There are plenty of other good places to eat in San Francisco!
author: Amy N.

description:
2/28/14  Lunch

This place I swear has been here for as long as I can remember. It's your hole-in-the-wall ethnic experience. A Chinatown staple. I decided to come here because I was nearby for eye glasses appointment. Golden King on Clay has been my go-to place but today, just as I was going to go there, I realize I should give My Canh a try.
