No biggie, most small asian resturants in China town are probably the same way.
author: Peter D.

description:
LOVE THIS PLACE! cool place to come after you're drunk from the club/bar but its kinda small FYI.

Just order Banh Canh Cua, kind of little with the crab so if you're kinda shady pay a little more if you ask for extra  meat. 

annnnnndddd Bo Tai Chanh!!!!!! Best raw meat you'll ever eat , i'm telling you  it shits on the rest of the bo tai chanh I've ever tried in my life.

and those are the two main dishes everyone's fussing about :)
author: Elle T.

description: We came from san jose to san Francisco just to eat banh canh cua here, its that great tasting here, highly recommend.  I also recommend here to eat bo tao chanh,  which is non cook thin slice beef over sour fish sauce, and veggies mix.  Fast friendly service and great hospitality environment. We will come again and again...highly recommended!
author: TôiyêuVN ..

description: Authentic prepared vietnamese noodle soup dishes: warm and satisfying  for an early morning breakfast in a hole in the wall shop. I ordered the Crab Meat Noodle Soup which I've never had before. There were claw crabmeat pieces with a very thick broth, very eggy. I tried the Bun Rieu too and my friend that eats that dish all the time says this was one of her top faves. I enjoyed it with lots of lime. Another small tip: the canned sodas they sell are $2 a pop which is a rip off so beware!
author: Briget P.

description: My housemate recommended  this place while we were in chinatown after the hike. I was kinda skeptical at first, but she told me..don't let the outside appearance fool you cause look can be deceiving. So we ended up coming here. We got the banh canh cua which was good, the broth was good but it was kinda hard to eat the crab since it wasn't peeled and they were out of the peeled one? I just don't know why they can't just peel it out for us. We also ordered the chicken salad which has a very distinctive flavor and very good. And I got the lemon beef salad ( bo tai chanh) which was delicious. It was probably the best bo tai chanh I've ever ate...I will definitely come back just for that salad.
author: Ngoc L.

description: I had the Banh Canh Cua like everyone had raved about but was highly disappointed.  I've had wayyyyy better.  There was hardly any crab meat and noodles and mostly thick overstarched broth.
author: Ha T.

description:
Let me set this up, scenario 1: food at 2am after the clubs and bars are closed and you are drunk and walking around looking for food- 4 stars

Scenario 2: compared to all foods in general, 1 star

The pho is super bland. Their egg rolls are extra greasy and not flavorful.  Their supposedly famous crab noodle soup was udon noodles in neon yellow gelatin soup base with what I suspect is frozen crab.  It is very bland and i'm usually a broth monster... let's just say there was plenty of broth left that night.  Though one thing I want to mention is on the menu, the crab noodle soup doesn't list a price but says Market Price- it's $10 folks- this is not some fancy seafood place. 

So where did the extra star come from?  Their service.  Not that it was exceptional, but you get what you need done, they try to seat you quickly and give you food quickly so you can get the hell outta there and they can seat more customers.  But, they do deal with tons of dumb drunk people, I think that definitely deserves an extra star.
author: Krystal C.

description:
I've come here a bunch of times now because it's soo close to where I live. I rate it great pho, pretty good service, and not that crowded/busy.

The atmosphere is hole-in-the-wall and super casual. I've come in sweatpants post-fun-night-out. Pho is the perfect food the console a weak stomach. They serve it fast and the broth and noodles are a pretty good combo of flavor. Friend also really likes the crab noodles, but I usually just stick with my favesies pho.

Cash only, and don't order pho to go. It tastes super weird. And they don't give you sriracha or hoison packets. F. 

Heard it's great for late night... can't wait to try that.
author: Adele Z.

description: Their banh canh cua still stands as #1 for me except that they seem to put less crab now and more meat instead. There awesome bo tai chanh hasn't change a bit since i was last there. Still is a great place to eat. Definitely a keeper!
author: Loan T.

description:
1.) Raw Beef Salad = omg. so good. I guess it's the same raw beef they throw into the pho, but it's chilled on some veggies mm refreshing and tasty!
2.) Beef Beefball Pho = Mmmm broth was good. Noodles were all in one clump, but after loosening it up it was still good. For a large, it wasn't that large

SERVICE:
Oh, you know. Muggin-asian service

ATMOSPHERE:
haha after hours drunk spot... Small pho place. Kind of ghetto bc it's a weekend at Broadway.. haha but o wells, it's good eatin's late night.
author: Angela L.

description: This is a pretty gnarly little Vietnamese place on Broadway with some cute old ladies who cook the food on some awesome little gas flame burners. I would usually order a chicken wrap to go, run some errands and then come back and grab the food. It has some kind of healthy tasting cilantro in it with a trippy, translucent rice tortilla.
author: Avram K.

description:
Came here with the gf and her mother, as this is a well-known hole for Vietnamese food, specializing in Dungeness crab soup and beef carpaccio.

The crab soup is VERY tasty.  The soup has the fresh crab taste, not the artificial one that can be someone nauseating at times.  It comes with udon noodles (not my favorite type) and not very much of it.  There is also a paucity of crab, maybe a couple legs inside so there is not much substance in the bowl itself.  I prefer some way to carb load when I have soup, so I was a bit disappointed and had to have another meal 3-4 hours later.

The beef carpaccio is also pretty good, topped with cilantro, mixed greens, lemon, crushed garlic, and a few other difficult-to-identify toppings which provided for a well balanced dish.  Without good reason, I have a hard time eating raw beef from a place that restaurant that doesn't seem exceedingly clean.

I was glad to try this place because I haven't had the crab soup before (Banh Canh Cua), but I do not think I will be back.
author: Chia C.

description: Their banh canh cua is the best I ever had ! I been here about 5 times. Only because I live in sacramento. If I was near by I would go there more often.
author: Nguyen L.

description: i understand why this place has mixed reviews. the banh canh cua is not consistent enough to live up to its famous name. but to be honest it is one of the best places in all the lands. my best friend and i went with our boys late one night to satisfy her sudden craving, but it was a disappointment for a 45 mins drive. it wasn't flavorful compared to my last visit and the crab meat was shredded when i only asked for it without the shell. but the chicken salad (goi ga) was so delicious it made everything worth it! i was so full after my bowl of banh canh but there was no way i was going to let the bf finish that salad by himself!
author: Thuong D.

description:
So i was feeling some BBH after night class on a tuesday and i decide to make my way over to broadway to My Canh which is open late. Scored front row parking due to it being just a weekday and no wait! Order the usual Bun Bo Hue (spicy) and damn was i satisfied. Steamy hot to order with pork meat, cube blood, and rib eye beef in a flavorful spicy broth! You did me justice tonight My Canh and i thank you for that! 


PS- They just slightly updated this place with new paint and the kitchen looks cleaner with new appliances. So make your way here for some bomb as BBH in the city!
author: Jacinta D.

description:
surprisingly fantastic food for a walk-by takeout at 9p. we had the beef ball egg noodle soup and spice beef ho fun soup (stew beef and sliced beef in spicy broth)  - both were great, with really flavorful broth and no cloying sweetness like you get in a lot of pho broth. the prices are pretty average for the area (6.45 for soup noodles) although a lot less expensive than their neighbor two blocks down.

don't expect big service at a hole in the wall kind of place, and remember that eating in Chinatown means eating in a normal small Asian restaurant. but definitely, definitely go.
author: Naomi L.

description: My friend took me to this place yesterday for the crab udon noodles. It was delicious and tasty. Must try!
author: Linh L.

description:
Why even go to the other side of town for some pho when I live on a block with pho shops of every corner??.. Well bc sometimes you just wanna get away. Well actually I was really down in Chinatown for some egg tarts and was craving pho, so we ended up here and it doesn't hurt that it stays open late as well. 

Bun bo hue!. Yep, I love their spicy broth, it makes those cold freezing temperature nites in sf worth it :)
author: Anonymous P.

description:
Really, the 3 stars are only for the fact that it's open late at night. Yelp claims until 2am, but they were letting people in much later. Clearly there's some $$ to make from drunk Asians, so don't be surprised if they skimp on the meat and "forget" the sides (basil, lime, mung beans). Oh, and I don't recommend ordering the shrimp rolls - definitely not the freshest at 2am. 

Huge plus that there's a restroom.
author: Leily P.

description:
Great for late night after a night of drinking/partying. Its definitely a hole-in-the-wall, but it gets the job done. I cant say this is the best pho I've ever had. Yet, this is my favorite to go to in the Chinatown area. It is convenient located near the clubs and bars on Broadway/Stockton/Columbus.  

Price range: 7-8/bowl.
author: Becky Q.

description:
At 200AM I get this place confused with Vietnam Restaurant.  I only know I'm in My Canh because there is a lot more seating.  A couple of friends and I ended up ordering a boatload of appetizers and pho and there were all pretty good.  The food is served extremely hot and fast and the prices are very reasonable.

I still think I prefer Vietnam Restaurant over this place because of the banh mi but this is a formidable alternative if Vietnam Restaurant is too busy.  It's fast, cheap and cash only, standard Vietnamese.
author: Mike T.

description:
I love this place. Very hole in the wall. But where else can you get some late night pho in the city? The restaurant itself isn't aesthetically pleasing, but who cares when you're beasting on a bowl of delicious pho. Like most pho spots, the food comes out pretty quickly. I usually order pho w/ tripe, flank, & beef balls but I heard their pho w/ dungeness crab is off the hook! I must try that the next time I come here, especially when its crab season, nomz. After a long intoxicated night on Broadway, a nice hot bowl of pho at My Canh will sober you up.

Tip: CASH ONLY! Also beware of your bill for those going late night, they'll try to rip off your (most likely) drunk ass.
author: BrendaJoy G.

description:
Favorite hole in the wall, pho restaurant that stays open pass 2am in all of SF. (please let me know if there are others out there that I don't know of)

Place is dirty, doesn't smell clean, but it does its job after a night of abusing the liver.  CASH ONLY! 

Love the pho, the raw beef Vietnamese carpaccio and the egg roll. 

Been coming here for ever 10 years, food is consistent. Don't expect much service, its located in broadway chinatown! 

I WILL BE BACK!
author: Chanel L.

description:
My buddies and I came by after an amazing night at Ruby Skye and we managed to run in before they closed at 3AM.

I had the beef stew with noodles and it was good BUT reaaaaallyyyyy oily. Oily like "thanks man, my poop is going to come out easier with all of this lube". The beef was actually really tender and delicious but the oil made everything a little unpleasant.

The place looks pretty run down, kind of expected from an Asian restaurant around this area. Sometimes that means really good food but didn't really work in my advantage this time.

***CASH ONLY***
author: Harry T.

description:
The best hole in the wall in San Francisco for Vietnamese food after a long night of partying...I will also drive an hour out of my way for your Udon noodle soup with crab (Banh Canh Cua) and your Raw Beef in lime juice (Bo Tai Chanh). There are so many other dishes i want to try but my stomach is not big enough, and i don't want to miss out on my two favorites every time i come here. :(

Don't expect any thing fancy, people come here for the wonderful food and not for the service nor the atmosphere. I wish you guys were closer so i don't have to spend $50 on gas for driving there, when i can spend it all on your so delicious food! I believe it's still CASH only, so be prepared!!
author: Tuyen H.

description:
Their so-called "infamous" Banh Canh Cua was definitely overrated. After hearing so many people rave about this place, I was expecting to taste something extremely tasty and flavorful. Well it was extremely tasteless in my opinion. We came with a group of 8, and everyone was pretty disappointed. The thick broth was quite plain. We had to add a bunch of extra side condiments to spice up the flavor. Came with broken up pieces of crab with the shell on, and some slices of pork. We didn't know that asking them to take the shells off the crab was an option - would've made eating it with the soup so much easier. Instead, we just left most of the crab untouched. 

It's a small hole-in-the wall type of restaurant. Not the cleanest, but at least the food came out quick. Not many tables and seems to get overly crowded. Would I come back here again? Probably not.
author: Cathy N.

description:
i absolutely love this place! And not just because I was usually drunk when I first started going here.  It is damn good food.  I usually get the Vermicelli with chicken and an eggroll but the shrimp fried rice, raw beef salad, and Seafood with crab pho are amazing! The guy that's usually there late seems to always have on a mean face but he's a nice guy so don't let that face fool you! He always remembers to bring my friend and I a small bowl of pho along with our order.
One of thee best hole-in-the-wall hot spots yet!
author: Daisy D.

description: Late night Pho or cold vermacelli with beef is bomb. They are open until at least 2AM and are speedy. The actual restaurant leaves something to be desired but whatev, it's on Broadway what do you expect.
author: Emma H.

description:
Omgosh! First off The Bo tai Chanh is bomb.

Since it was my first time here i didn't know what to order and I've been hearing people rave about their canh cua. So its easy to say that we should try it. The soup was thick and flavorful!  

Service wise... Ummm, its hard to say anything about that. Come on now, at the time i was there it was post club hr so you can only imagine the craziness going on.
author: Hong T.

description:
After all the recent inconsistencies I had experienced at VR, a revised review of MC was needed.
Compared to VR, you do get lower prices and more meat on the dishes at MC, although their veggies look dull.  Also you get more elbow room because the space is bigger and it's all table seats.

So for Round Two: MC manages to tie with VR!
author: Luis C.

description:
Food: 3

They speak/look Vietnamese - we ordered: Banh Canh Cua, Bun Bo Hue, Banh Xeo... Review to follow


This place closes at 2am! Oh lawdy we in trouble!

My girlfriend and I ordered the above dishes and although we're decent, it lacked skill and flavour, but very authentic. 

Go here if you've been out drinking out in North Beach or at the edge of Chinatown!
author: Christopher L.

description: I've had the bun rieu twice from this place, and both times it tasted like a polar-opposite extreme. My first bowl tasted like stardard bun rieu. However, the second bowl (at another time) tasted like the broth was diluted.  Apparently, inconsistency is the problem here. Perhaps, the next time warrants something deep-fried instead.
author: Derek N.

description:
I love the banh canh cua from this restaurant. I don't live in SF but would drive to SF just to have their wonderful banh canh cua. What do they put in there to make it so good?!?! I have yet found a replacement for this place's banh canh cua. I have searched and tasted so many different restaurant's banh canh cua in San Jose area, but nothing was as comparable to theirs. The banh canh cua is the Vietnamese udon noodle soup. It's thick noodle soup but not only is the noodle thick but the soup is  thick as well with great flavors. In the soup there are pork meat, pork blood, crab(yummy), fried onions with green onions, and a few more but I can't recollect the exact details.They have a slice of lemon on the side for you to squeeze it in. The soup is already so very tasty, but the lemon juice really enhances the flavor to the max level. Just thinking about it makes me drool. I want to drive to SF right now and get myself some banh canh cua. Not only do I eat the noodle soup there at the restaurant, but I also togo two of them home. Yes, 2 orders. Whenever I'm in SF area, I usually always make a stop at My Canh for their amazing banh canh cua.

I ducted one star off is because majority of the times, it's difficult to find a parking space. I would have to park in the garage and pay 5-7$. Yikes, that's a lot, especially because it accumulates! Not only is the parking hard to find, but the restaurant is not very clean.It's a small restaurant. It's a family owned restaurant (that's what they told my family when we asked). I don't mind that much, that the restaurant is not very clean but the restroom is ghetto. I was just there last month and when I went to use the restroom, I was shocked to see there was no cover toilet seat! No, I'm not talking about the paper toilet covers but the cover toilet seat for the ladies to seat down to do their business. I don't know if they were in the processed of fixing their toilet or if they are just going to leave it like that, but oh my lordy that was an ugly sight. This place actually deserves a 3.5 but because of the amazing canh banh cua and other flavorful dishes, I am giving this place 4 stars. I will continue to be a patron here for the mighty banh canh cua.
author: Ngoc P.

description:
If you're craving for pho after drinking hours, this is the place to look. The food is not bad, that's why they get 1 star. The ONLY warning (and the only reason why I'm writing this review) is to be careful when the bill comes. The lady will ALWAYS try to get a few extra $ out of you when she knows you have alcohol in you. Our bill was $109 and we paid $120. She still comes back and says we shorted us $9. This wasn't the first time either.. 

All in all, if you decide to go, decent food- just be careful when the bill comes!
author: Miss Y.

description:
3 stars for food.
4 for open late.  Till 2.
If you're visiting that late, parking should be no issues.  They are one of the few Vietnamese places open past 10 in the city.  Run by Cantonese folk.  The soup is standard.  Not great, not bad.  

Oddly enough, the hole in the wall few doors down the street (viet, not pizza) is just as good, open just as late, just no tables.

Do the pho, or something with fried egg on top of it.  That's pretty much what you'd crave at 1 a.m. and the only thing you should order from this place anyway.

Cash only.  Blah.  Get with the fucking times.

Did I say it was open late?  Good for late night only.
author: HQ G.

description: Chose the grilled beef and egg roll noodle salad. It was so-so. Something good to eat when you spent a night out of drinking and needed to fill your stomach with something. It didn't live up to what I would expect good Vietnamese food to be or what I'm normally used to.
author: Kai V.

description: Service is fast and food is great. I had their bun bo hue with small noodles and this is more of a filler up than their thicker noodles. I would say its not that authentic but it's good enough for me to not drive to San Jose for a bowl. This bowl of spicy noodle soup will work for me. I had their beef carpaccio and to be honest, it was amazing before but they cut their meat a lot thicker now so its pretty tough to chew and swallow. If it was thinner, then it'll be a very delicious dish.  Their regular noodle soup hits the spot after a night of clubbing and drinking.  But.....be sure to drink a lot of water because I woke up with a dry mouth. Hydrate please! A lot of MSG in their food but still an awesome place for a quick pho fix late at night.
author: Irene L.

description: Pricey, bare decor, half-cleaned tables and chairs, with a menu and food served quickly but I was one of three others there, plus they were already eating. Cash only, big plate servings but no taste. I have been to other Vietnamese restaurants that had better prices, service and taste. This place has high prices!! I had the chicken noodle soup and the pork with vegetables, both tasteless. I will not be returning. How good was this place? I didn't snap one pix!! Had to ask three times for a soup bowl - how difficult is that to have when served a soup?
author: Tony L.

description:
-Went there after a hangover sort of night. So of course I had to order some type of breakfast plates.(Love breakfast plates after a night of drinking) Had the pork chops w/ egg and rice. Super delish, can't go wrong with that.

-Had a taste of my friends soups. I really enjoyed the seafood noodle soup. (Don't know the vietnamese name sorry)

-Hole in the wall, cheap. Parking's pretty bad.
author: Daisy M.

description:
#9 bun cha gio ga nuong

rice noodle with imperial rolls, pork meatball and grilled chicken

After a crazy walk with B2B, I was starving!! I've never had this dish before until I came here. And now I'm hooked! I will definitely come back and have #9 again! :)

This is a totally random place between North Beach and Chinatown border.
author: CeCe C.

description:
In 1998 I lived in Hanoi and HCMC as an ESL teacher. The food at My Cahn reminds me of the typical place most people would eat. Not excessive or fancy, but a good meal and enough flavor to make it enjoyable. Also, healthy because there are none of the typical"excessiveness." In both Hanoi and HCMC, one can find fancy foods with fancy sauces and spices, but that isn't where "the people" eat.  My Cahn is typical, especially the various Pho's. 
   Beyond the flavor the service is friendly, helpful, but there is a very slight language struggle...but it is no problem. The setting is a bit untidy, but that is no problem either.  If you want fancy-fancy, go a block away into North Beach. If you just want a nice VN meal, enjoy it here. Healthy? I have eaten here at least 25 times with my wife and we have never had an adverse experience. 
   After having soup there tonight, I realized, "These guys deserve a good review."
author: Mark H.

description: This is my nitch place I've been going to since I was little. Always came with the fam to eat pho but now I've grown and upgraded my tastes to a different restaurant (for pho at least). But I do come here for their Bun Rieu. Very standard and delicious. The people are nice and accommodating regardless of how many new faces I've seen over the years. It wasn't until a few years ago that I found out that this place closes late. So if you're straggling around in Chinatown at night, hit this place up!
author: Sophia K.

description: I come here for their banh canh cua (crab meat soup) every time when I visit SF...just my luck they ran out of crab meat. Service is terrible but you expect that in China town.
author: Thy M.

description:
There really needs to be another late night pho in SF place besides this one. The food is okay but I agree with other yelpers that they do skimp out and "forget" the sides basil leaves, mung beans, and lime for our pho. I mean we ordered 3 bowls...I don't know how in the world they would think that we wouldn't notice it. There was another set of staff or maybe a family that used to own this location and they changed hands sometime last year I believe and the old staff was much friendlier and more generous. 

The service is nonexistent and you do have to wave someone down even when there are only two tables full but eh I didn't have high expectations walking into this place at 11 pm on a Saturday night.
author: Crystal C.

description:
I really like their banh canh cua. This place is a hole in the wall, so it might be a bit difficult trying to find it the first time. 

The restaurant is also kind of worn and could use some aesthetic improvements, but so do most places in this area of the city. 

This restaurant is known for the banh canh cua, which is a kind of noodle soup dish that has Vietnamese udon, pork blood cubes, dungeness crab, and other goodies in it. It was divine here. The broth is so sweet from the crab and seafood -- the broth is also very sweet and kind of has a light viscosity to it that I find very appealing. It was more than a broth but much less than a chowder. 

I usually don't like soup-y foods too much, and I never can finish a whole bowl of pho (even the small portion), and I gobbled up the whole thing -- broth and all -- here. 

Squeezing a bit of fresh lemon or lime juice on the hot bowl of banh canh cua with a few squirts of sriracha make this dish absolutely heavenly. 

San Francisco is known for dungeness crab, so be sure to try this place out!

TIP: They do use fresh crab, so it's best to come here during dungeness crab season. Otherwise, most likely, the smaller less flavorful red crabs will be used in the banh canh, and it is not as delicious. If you're a crab fanatic, this will be of utmost importance! 

Enjoy! I crave this food on cold winter nights. So good.
author: Anh D.

description:
This place is average. We had the "beef carpaccio" and it was delicious. It had a lot of flavor and the freshness of the mint pairs well with the thin beef. The added crunchy onions gives it a good crunchy contrast. The dish is around $14. The rice dish was pretty standard,  although they give you two pork chops, instead of one, which is good.

However, the banh canh cua (crap soup) was very disappointing. The soup is thick, like they pour a cup of cornstarch in it. It was not good at all. 

The fried eggrolls are good too, I would order that again. 

I do like the fact that this place is open late, till 2am.
author: Jun W.

description: I have mixed feelings about this place. On a long crazy night in the city , this is a really legit spot for late night eats. The food is good , but it's small , a little on the greasy spoon side, and the service is not surprisingly non existent . I continue to come here because I get exactly what I expect , which is a little tricky these days. Recco's or the pho , the 5 spice chicken , and the raw beef salad ( not on the menu, but trust me). If anything else was open till 4am i'd still come here to eat.
author: Bryan Y.

description:
rib with rice better next door.
my friend recommend me to come here , maybe I ordered the wrong dish.
will come back and try again
author: Rina C.

description:
Came here because it said it closes at 2AM. So yea...

When we came inside, it was super dirty, we weren't really greeted and we just sat wherever. The waiter finally acknowledges us and drops off 2 menus RUDELY. Like WTH man!? Anyway, we ordered the regular rare steak pho and it was surprisingly good. Tasted better than the 24HR pho I had the week before in Vegas and that place was super clean.

Super hole in the wall but it was good. 
Remember to bring cash because that's all they accept.
author: Criselle O.

description: I came from out of town and was told this place was super good. I ordered the crab banh canh, which I thought was simply okay. There wasn't anything special about the bowl, however I did appreciate the fact that they put real crab meat. I thought the soup was good, but added spice to it because that is how I like it. I might be back if I am nearby, but definitely not my must go to place.
author: Diane N.

description: Great little place reminds me of Vietnam with the setting and sacks of rice on the floor. Extremely well priced & fresh food that fills a family. Good for kids to get a SE Asian experience. Try the won ton soup or pork salad.
author: Llew J.

description:
Best drunk food =  late night pho...open till 3 or 4am on weekends, you can't find it anywhere else. simply the BEST! 

don't forget to order the raw beef appetizer. "Bor die zhennnn" ... : )
author: Sandy L.

description: Definitely your hole in the wall joint. Major plus, open late! Tried the Tai Pho and Beef Carpaccio before, both were delicious. But what really gets me coming back here is their CRAB PHO! With udon noodles, a thick broth, and real crab meat...mmm! The service could use some working on, but then again there is a language barrier so it's understandable. I don't care what people say, THE CRAB PHO IS A MUST TRY!
author: Marissa C.

description:
Very shady and rude.  They humiliated me in front of whole bunch of customers by shouting at me telling me "You don't want to eat then get the hell out!"

OK this is what happened.  You be the judge.  I went to this restaurant late at night.  It was not a busy night.  Just few tables.  I was hungry so I ordered an extra large bowl of number one beef noodle soup.  Then they brought out this very tiny bowl of soup.  Then a large group of young kids came in.  They were about to order.  Then I called the waitor and said "Excuse me sir.  I order an extra large bowl.  You gave me the wrong size ." This bowl is so small its for ripping of tourists.  I am not a tourist.  I eat at Vietnamese foods all the time.  And they charge almost $9 for a X large bowl.  Then waitor and the owner both ignored me.  Then I kept complaining about how small your extra large bowl is.  I am not a stupid tourist who will pay $9 for this tiny bowl.  Then one of the owners got angry and came toward me with an empty bowl and loudly said "Look!  This is our medium size bowl.  You compare it yourself!  Your bowl is so much bigger!"  I said "Oh yeah?"  And I just poured my entire soup noodle which I never had a single bite into that medium size bowl she brought.  And guess what?  The entire content did not even reach the top of that bowl.  It's like one full inch below the top.  This shows that my bowl is even smaller than their medium size bowl because the soup reached the top of my  bowl.  Then I spoke out loud since that woman spoke to me very loud.  I said "You see?  Your medium size bowl is way bigger than my bowl.  So this is not the extra large bowl I ordered is it?"  Then she got embarrassed and immediately yelled at me and said "OK you don't want to eat then you get out!"  All those other young kid customers were laughing and as I walked out I heard these young kids placing their orders.   One kid said he wants a medium size bowl of some soup.  Then another kid also said he wants just a medium size of some noodle soup.  Then another said "Excuse me.  I want to cancel my large size soup noodle and just go for the medium size."   Nobody dared to order their X large bowl anymore after what they saw.  Terrible service.  Very unfair and shady.  Maybe they never saw me before so they figure its okay to give me a tourist treatment.  But actually I ate their before several times but not very often.  Or maybe they did not have enough soup that night.  What ever the deal is I am writing them up on Yelp.

Oh yeah I just remembered something.  Much earlier, maybe 4 years ago me and my friend were eating at this same restaurant and it was Chinese new year eve.  That same waitor who gave me the tiny bowl of X large soup opened the front glass door and starting blowing up those Chinese red fire crackers that are linked together in a long chain.  The door was opened and he blew them up only like 12 feet away from our table. It was so loud it was breaking our ear drums.  Both me and my friend told him to stop blowing it up.  But that waitor totally ignored our request and just kept blowing up that chain of fire crackers.  We kept telling him to stop or at least shut the door for us and blow it outside.  But he simply pretended that he did not hear us.  Then after like a minute the fire crackers stopped popping.  Finally we can take our fingers out of our ears.  Then guess what?  This waitor took out another round of fire crackers and blew them up at the door.  Pop Pop Pop!  None stop.  Wow I was thinking this guy basically don't care about the customers at all.
author: Alex C.

description:
Sanitation wise, it was pretty bad but what do you expect from a whole in the wall place. Therefore, my review will be based upon the chicken clay pot dish. I couldn't order their specialty dish which was the crab noodle due to personal reason, but the broth was good. 

So down to the chicken rice clay pot. I wished the rice would have cooked more to give that crispy edge because I felt that I was eating just chicken, vegetables, and rice. Overall, the dish was very bland.

This is a cash ONLY place...
author: Nhung T.

description:
Make no mistake, the banh canh was solid. Seems like this is a popular late night spot, but I came here with the parents after a tour of Chinatown in the afternoon. Yes, every time I've been to SF Chinatown, I've eaten at a Thai, and now a Vietnamese restaurant. Go figure.

The location is fairly easy to find on Broadway with a large sign out front. Inside it's a hole-in-the-wall feel with 4-5 tables along a wall with the kitchen to the right. Service was very typical for an asian restaurant, ie. they do the minimum effort necessary, and you have to yell at them to get any service. Didn't get my water refilled once. Had to yell to get my check.

The banh canh itself was fairly solid, at the upper end of the price range at $9.50/bowl (market price) The soup was flavorful and thick, and contained various bits of pork and pieces of crab. I like the fact the crab is in the shell, but it makes the banh canh a bit harder to eat, and less enjoyable. All in all it's a solid 4/5 bowl, maybe a tad on the salty side, but the service and the rude atmosphere knocks it down half a star.

Maybe I'll try the bo tai chanh next time.
3.5/5 stars.
author: John Paul P.

description:
For late night pho or Vietnamese noodles and rice plates in the city after a night of clubbing on Broadway, you can't go wrong with My Canh. It's open seemingly all night and the food comes fast and hot.

I always go with the pho which is actually quality noodles and meat. My friends like the special seafood noodle dishes with real whole crab and squid.

I definitely recommend going here after a night of drinks.
author: Chuck N.

description: We stumbled upon this place after a late night in San Francisco. Our friends wanted Vietnamese soup and remembered having a really great seafood noodle soup around the area. After driving around, they remembered the blue awning outside and the next thing we know, we sat down and ordered 4 Banh Canh Cua.  Having grown up in the South Bay, I can say I have had the best and the worst Banh Canh Cua's.  My Canh's version is pretty tasty. They definitely are pretty generous with the fresh crab. I can't say I'll return because it's pretty out of the way for me.  But if it were another late night and I was in the area, I'd definitely consider it.
author: Diana T.

description:
There are MANY places to have pho.  In my opinion, I haven't experienced "bad" pho.  This place satisfied our late night craving after a concert.  The place is small and it was packed.  It looked like half of the customers came from the Giants game that night.

The pho is pretty good - standard fare.  Price is fairly cheap.  The service really is VERY bad.  We waited almost 40 minutes for 3 bowls of pho.  We'll come back if and only if there's no other pho place open nearby.  Otherwise, WE PASS.
author: Will C.

description: The best chicken egg noodle pho ever!! Better than I've had at many other pho places. The imperial rolls are pretty good according to my friends (I don't eat pork but they look super delicious) my boyfriend also really likes their rare beef pho (#25) they can custom make things if you ask them, when I'm low carbing I ask them to make me tofu, shrimp and broccoli and they make it delicious and no problem. They are open til about 3am but my friends and i have went around 4am and they still let us eat while they clean, i think its because we are regulars... The reason I'm only giving them 3 stars is because its not the cleanest place  and sometimes the waiter that we always see is still kinda rude and never smiles at us... Lol
author: Karah S.

description:
this place used to be better... 

i alwaysss get the banh canh cua and the bo tai chanh... (crab udon and raw beef salad).. those r the best items on the menu.... 

service is slow and a little rude.. and honestly, maybe i just wasnt drunk enough these last couple times, but the food just wasnt the same..
author: Lisa N.

description:
I only come here for the beef pho( #24 on the menu). So my four star rating is based on only this food. 

I've tried pho at other places that are supposedly better (they're not), but for the price and taste, my canh is still my favorite. 

If you don't mind the occasional fly (the doors are usually open so maybe that's why?) or sharing a table with a stranger during busy hours , or hearing the staff shout at each other in vietnamese, then try this place. They are open til 2am if I'm not mistaken so it's great if ever you get a craving for pho at midnight or if you're coming home drunk/hungry and just want something warm for your tummy.
author: Paula U.

description: Best Bun canh cua everrrrrrrrrrrrr! :)
author: linda L.

description:
Service with a scowl,
My noodles taste like old oil.
Late-night crowd: really?
author: Adriana V.

description:
#25 meat on the side

another drunken meal, came here after the club in SF.. as usual it was crowded as hell!
not the cleanest place, waiting for a table takes forever... but its delicious!
located on broadway st. next to the bars/clubs/massage parlors/exotic dancing businesses!

all you need.. great spot.

cash only, saw some poor drunk white boy get messed up because he wasn't sober enough to pay for his meal!
author: Braden K.

description:
Came here after doing a Yelp search afer a late night out and we were craving pho.

Small, divey hole in the wall.  Not the best pho i've had but the food hit the spot for a midnight bite. Had the beef pho (#24). Meat's a little fatty (maybe go with the rare steak (#25) next time), the serving is on the smaller side, and the bean sprouts and mint leaves were wilted and not that fresh.

Still, can't be too picky late night.  But next time, if i check out this place again, I'll try the Banh Canh Cua (Crab Noodle Soup), which is supposed to be good here.  The Bo Tai Chanh (Beef Carpaccio) also gets rave reviews here but not as excited to try that.
author: F. P.

description: I first visited this place couple years ago for their famous Crab noodle soup and chicken salad. I came back pretty often but the food just doesn't taste as good as before. Hopefully, they will up their game in the future.
author: Miss D T.

description: For $7, I wasn't expecting the world. That being said, my bowl of Pho wasn't exactly spectacular. The slices of beef were pretty small and the tripe wasn't the best (not the typical spongy tripe you get at a more higher end place, but rather the gummy other parts). So if you need a quick fix (and it certainly was quick) this could be your place. Otherwise, I'll spend a dollar or two extra for the better meaty bits.
author: Janelle A.

description: Not too many places serve bun bo hue and it's my default if it's on the menu.  One cold late night, we came here looking for a hot bowl of noodle soup.  With bun bo hue on the menu, all 3 of us ordered it and mine extra spicy.  Unfortunately, it was just ok at best and not authentic with cooked bean sprouts at bottom, very little noodles, slices of pork with no pig feet but blood cake was pretty good.
author: Gloria H.

description: Real simple, no frills. Had the pho, it was tasty enough. Just be warned: CASH ONLY Y'ALL.
author: Leslie C.

description:
"I love eating food in my can."
"Let's go to the can and eat some food."
"Food eaten on my can is so good."
"I need to go to the can to get some pho"

My Canh's name provides endless entertainment for us simple minded folks. Potty humor will never die in my book.

Eons ago I had the 5 spice chicken vermicelli bowl and it has yet to be matched.  The marinade was delicious and the meat cooked perfectly.  Now that I am doing the whole pescetarian (wussy vegetarian) lifestyle, I tried the grilled shrimp bowl and it proved to be mighty satisfying. The shrimp was nicely seasoned and deveined, but dry.  I would definitely have it again as I know that it is the best Vietnamese in North Beach, but I will be sure to have a yen moment for Richmond's Little Vietnam Cafe.

Two bowls of happiness and a pot of tea cost us $13.  

"You can get cheap food in my can."
author: Hayley W.

description: Talk about hole in the wall (which I Love!!) - perhaps one time where I would have liked to really sit down and enjoy the food but was, instead, parked on the "counter" with the high chairs - a little too cold to sit outside.  That aside, food was really good - had their Imperial Rolls (outstanding) and Pho (mixed beef) - all good quality and nice people working there - probably better for take out than dine in.
author: Richard D.

description:
So good it even made lunch with my ex-girlfriend pleasant.  As you all know, open after 2am gets an extra star from me so this explains the 5 stars. My Canh is some of the best vietnamese food I've tasted in town. I am nuts about pho, but after reading yelp I tried the banh canh cua and now I have to struggle between whether to order that or pho tai with tripe. 

The decor is horrible. The service is marginal. The food is worth it all and more. Go now.
author: Darren M.

description: Their known for their banh canh so that's what I tried.  Very good, you get an actually crab leg in your soup.  The place is run down, customer service is okay. If I was in the neighborhood I would definitely come back.
author: jen l.

description: The last time I was at My Canh a big ass fight broke out between a couple and her friend. It was sad and fucked up. So here I am sitting with six of my girlfriends BUZZED from drinking and dancing all night...we are sitting at the table waiting for our banh canh cua and bo tai chanh (beef carpacio) and all of a sudden the table 10 feet away from us starts yelling. We try not to look over but c'mon the restaurant itself seats about 15 people and its definitely a HOLE IN THE WALL kind of a spot. The guy looks over at his girlfriend and FLIPS the table!!!!! The banch canh spilled all over the place and her friend tripped getting up :( I felt so bad for the girls. It was uncalled for and so unnecessary.  Anyway, I still love the food because the banh canh cua and bo tai chanh is to die for and I don't care what anyone says.....there is nothing like this is anywhere else. I'm definitely a full blown bay girl and I have to say this spot has a special place in my heart.
author: Annie P.

description:
Nasty because it's such a dirty place and it looked so ghetto.  A hole in the wall place but not any good at all.

Their banh canh cua (crab soup) wasn't even good.  I tried it and I couldn't even finish half.  Their pho was edible for a late night hung over after clubbing but that's pretty much it.

I would only come here after clubbing in SF since they opened late and because I don't know of any other Vietnamese place that open late in SF.
author: Nina M.

description:
After freezing for two hours on a boat (for a friend's birthday celebration) in San Francisco Bay, My Canh was the perfect hole-in-the-wall to stop by and dine at before heading back home to San Jose. My friend couldn't remember how to get there and we got a little lost, but who doesn't in the City? To be very honest...after trying this place, I'd definitely make the drive again just for some of My Canh's delicious Bo Tai Chanh (Vietnamese Beef Carpaccio with Lemon) and Banh Canh Cua (Dungeness Crab Noodle Soup).

Appetizer: Bo Tai Chanh's portion was very generous--one plate was enough to feed about 4-5 people. It's basically thinly sliced beef Carpaccio, bathed in fresh lemon juice, perfectly complemented with slices of onion, cracked peanuts, thinly sliced jalapeno, dried/fried onions, and rau ram (Vietnamese coriander). The combination was DELICIOUS.

Their specialty: Banh Canh Cua is a thick soup with translucent udon/noodles, fresh Dungeness crab (shell and all), slices of pork, green onion, and chunks of pork blood. The thick, succulent soup warmed me up and definitely hit the spot. 

This place is pretty tiny and dingy, but the food is great. It's perfect for a place to dine at after a long night of partying in the City. Don't forget your cash though as it's cash only!
author: Lien T.

description:
I no longer go to the city looking forward to having a good time at the hippest club.  I solely look forward to the time afterwards when I can sit my sweaty ass down at this place and enjoy a steaming bowl of PHO.  

This place opens until 4 AM I believe and attracts all kinds of drunk people.  So minus one star.  But seriously as one of the drunkards, this place is so delicious after 2 AM.  

CHECK IT OUT
author: James H.

description:
Dear My Canh, 

Thank you for always being there to cap my night off with a memorable and  delicious meal. 

Please do not by any chance, ever change your menu or go away.  I am in love with your lemon raw beef topped with fried onions dish.  I dream about you in my sleep constantly. 

Your fried spring rolls make my mouth water and your crab noodle soup fills me with deepest contentment.  

When I am eating at your restaurant, nothing else exists. You were so good I completely forgot about the cute boy from the table next to mine.

Yours truely,
Tammy cao
author: tammy c.

description:
For a metropolitan city, San Francisco doesn't have a lot of late-night eateries, at least compared to Los Angeles and New York City.  We have Mel's (which sucks) and a couple of Korean restaurants (also not very good) - and a couple others but one would have to be completely PLASTERED and needing to eat out of necessity to enjoy the food.

There are two late-night restaurants that I do frequent where the food is basically pretty good.  Both happen to be in North Beach - which is one area in which I rarely hang out at night, so it's a bit inconvenient.  But this is Grace talking - - where won't I drive to for food?  

The first place is Yuet Lee, which offers some impressive Chinese food at an even more impressively cheap price.  In fact, this was the only place I would frequent up to a couple of months ago.  But their soup selection is weak, and when you need some good soup, noodles and a whole lot of MSG - you need "Pho".

For late-night Pho, My Canh is a great place.
The pho is pretty good. I'd give it a good 3-stars.  They give you a decent amount of meat, the noodles are cooked right, and the broth is good enough.  This is not Pho that will knock your socks off but at 1 AM - like I said, your choices are pretty meager. It will warm your tummy and at least make you feel better in the morning.

If you order their "raw beef" - they give you an amazing dish of flavors, piled high on their thin slivers of raw beef.  It's not on the menu - you have to ask. Even if you have reservations about raw beef - go try this.  It really is delicious.  I have to give this dish 5-stars.

Having been to My Canh now about 8 times in the last couple of months, their service is pretty consistently friendly.  They are accomodating in that I usually end up taking a group of 7+, and it's been as many as 12 people, and they will arrange the tables for you, move chairs, etc.

It's rather grungy in here, and I have to wonder about how sanitary the kitchen is.  But you know, when I am hungry and it's 2 AM, who really cares?  If it won't kill me, it's basically good enough for me.  If I can eat a plate of raw meat w/ lemon juice here and live to tell about it - it won't kill you.  (Well, unless it does, I guess -  which would be sad but how could I have known?)  There is one bathroom.  That, too, is grungy, but again - after a night of drinking, you really won't care too much.  I will say I have never seen so much Costco toilet paper in one place, piled all the way up to reach the ceiling.

For very good Pho, I still have to head to Pho Vietnam on Polk (which, so far, is the best I have found in San Francisco).  But serving good Pho there is really irrelevant when it's 1 AM and they close at 10 pm.  

So, when you're well into the night and you have the Asian affliction of needing SOUP after drinking - - My Canh is a good choice.  

Note:  Pho Saigon is right next door - and  there IS a difference so be careful which door you walk into when you're stumbling about looking for this place.
author: Grace K.

description: The rare beef pho was good. Broth was tasty. Imperial rolls were good. A bit dirty inside but I would go back.
author: Brooks D.

description: After a late night of dancing we headed over here for some banh canh. I got their special banh canh with crab. I didn't expect the crab to be actual crab legs and pieces. Those were too hard for me to eat so I gave them to my bf. The actual broth was super thick and super delish!
author: Kim l.

description:
This place is only good for late night snack since it's one of the only pho place that is opened late in the city.

Their pho here is below average. Soup is bland and full of MSG. They charge extra without telling in advance for beef on the side.

Friend saw rats running around in here before. Scared the crap out of some customers. You can also say this restaurant is dirty since everything is sticky..

Service is horrible. Waitress tried to keep the change for tips without customer's approval; even after they gave us poor service.

I only suggest this place if you are craving for pho 1-2 am in the morning. Otherwise, don't even bother... There are better pho places around.
author: Jannifer H.

description:
1 start for being open till 3am
1 star for nice people
1 star for a decent tasting pho
1 star for an excessive amount of tp in the bathroom (it'll be YEARS before they run out)

-1 for no heat especially with this 'snow weather' we are having  ( my pho got cold in like 5min )
-1 for not enough meat and not enough broth

if im craving pho late night i might go there again, but def wont go if there are other places open.
author: Shadi N.

description:
My friends and I are frequent at this place for Banh Canh Cua (crab meat noodle soup).   Apparently it's one of the most ordered dishes there.  Not necessarily the best Banh Canh Cua around, but perhaps the best in SF  under $10 after hours.

The place is normally overflowed after 2pm in weekends as clubbers need to recharge their engergy after dancing, courting or whatever...  I once wait for 45 mins to get to the table and another 45 mins to get a bowl of Banh Canh Cua that shrinks in content (the bowl is still the same size) in comparision to one I'd get in some earlier evenings.  And there's still a line outside.  It is around 3am.

Being so frequent there, servers and chef assistants and chefs know us by name.  They tell us "don't come here late in weekends, it's over crowded."  They actually add more crabs and noodle to the serving to make up the last time that they... shrink the bowl of Banh Canh Cua during rush hours.  8-)  The gesture is kinda cute!

It's definitely not a place u find the best ambiance, or the finest dining experience.  But for sure it's a place where u can get some good food cheap.  And remember, don't come after hours in weekends.
author: QC P.

description:
Tried this late night north beach pho spot (as well as Vietnam) next door on consecutive nights. The pho dac biet here came with more beef than it's neighbor and the cuts of beef and tendon were cooked slightly better here. The broth however lacked clarity as well as beefiness. 

This spot has the edge in terms of space, seating and turnover. You could finish a bowl of pho here and then some while the line next door hasn't budged.
author: Derrick V.

description:
Things have changed My Canh....

This is the fourth time Chong and I have come and the service has been so slow it could be described as brutally excruciating.  I ignored it the first three times because I understood that they were busy, and for as busy as it was the wait was understandable......

Last night, blunt number 2 and feeling hungry but not at all interested in the food the bar we were headed to had to offer, Chong vehemently insisted we get coconut curry with tofu & vegetables, her new alleged favorite dish. We get there and to our glee it's not as packed as usual and we sit at one of the four open tables. We wait about 15 minutes til the server finally took our order. 30 minutes and 3 new parties later..... our conversation turned into a struggle to keep our mind off the ridiculously long wait. We ordered spring rolls and coconut curry, a vegetarian dish that's usually on our table within ten minutes... but for some reason the past 3 visits, it's taken 20 [on this particular visit 30]. Chong was not pleased she felt like we were being ignored on purpose. I felt the same and she took note that the newer parties got their food before us. I have to tell you how hungry we were, I started eating the Nuoc Leo [peanut based dipping sauce] and mixing it with the chili and tasting it. Cheech & Chong were eating the condiments.... 

The food was good, there's no arguing that aspect, ever. But My Canh needs to return to how it was before, disposed to treat guests with cordiality. 

Chong gasped and looked at me when the bill came "Oh no I only have exact change...not enough for tip :( I'm so disheartened*sarcasm*" Not at all unfair in my opinion considering I don't get tipped as a server when I take a long time.
author: Myrtle M.

description: Had the pho and shrimp rolls. The only taste the broth had was MSG , like sooooo much of it. The noodles weren't good and the beef was gross. I thought the shrimp rolls were OK at first, until I took a bite without smothering it in sauce and realized the shrimp tasted kind of rotten. Major fail on all fronts. I wish there were other better Asian places open late
author: Angela Z.

description:
Filling.  Dingy.  Late-night.

Pho - not bad, not great, filling.

Service - Fast, impersonal.

Menu - Everything typical Viet, minus bahn mi sammies, plus crab nood soup

Setting - Scant, skin washing-fluorescent lights, spottily painted floor, no wall decor (that I can recall)

Open late.
It is what it is.
Will try crab noodle soup next time!
author: Jane L.

description:
Despite the surly service, I've had lunch here at least a dozen times in the past 2 years.  (I need pho...often!).  But no more!

I understand that that at 2 pm, the lunch rush is over and the employees who work here might want to take a load off to eat some pho themselves.  But really, don't just look at me look at you while you slurp your soup!  You could have at least handed me a friggin' menu.

I walked out and will never return.  I know some Asian (yeah, I said it!) restaurants can be a little...brisk, but this is ridiculous!

Screw y'allz.
author: Karen F.

description:
I'm a big big big fan of this place ! My family and I have been coming here ever since I was a little kid .

Their Bun Bo Hue, Pho Ga, and Crab Meat Noodle are SO GOOD !

This is the only place I come for the crab meat noodle soup . But instead, I ask them to replace the crab meat to pig's blood . YUM . The crab comes with the shell, and being as lazy as I am, I don't wanna knaw on it .

Sure the place isn't the cleanest restaurant in the world, but it's cheap, it's in chinatown, what'd you expect ? 

Just know one thing, IT'S DELICIOUS .

P.S. don't use their bathroom .
author: Jenny Y.

description:
There are 3 categories of cheap in my world: cheap, dirt cheap, and well... dirty cheap. Yes, dirty. And I don't mean that in a Christina Aguilera dirty way, I'm talking just plain flithy, smutty, moldy, there are enzymes growing in my water, dirty cheap. 

Now please forgive me for being a germaphobic princess, but hole in the walls have never been my cup of tea, especially when that's lukewarm tea they're serving you. I find comfort in sipping on a hot cup of tea while being able to reassure myself that the heat is burning any potential microbe that could possibly be swimming in my cup. However, My Canh shunned any hopes for germaphobic reassurance. As I entered the smutty looking restaurant, the wooden panels plastered on the wall left me displeased with their choice of decor and their exposed refrigerator filled with vegetables in pink plastic bags scattered next to soda cans left me feeling a little uneasy. The communal utensil container expedited my dormant anxiety as I reached over to grab a fork. I found myself touching not just one, but the other five surrounding forks that stood next to my chosen fork. A sudden make believe scene flashed within my head of past customers with filthy unwashed hands who reached for one fork but ended up contaminating the innocent forks that were to be left for the next guests. I cried silently inside to myself as I wiped my chosen fork on my napkin.

Now despite my lack of affinity towards My Canh's appearance and cleanliness, their food wasn't too bad. On a scale between decent and amazing, it fell somewhere short of great yet a little above good. Their menu had quite the selection, but my heart was set on getting late night pho. And not to mention, one of the main reasons we dipped into My Canh was the fact we got out of the gym around 10:30 and were craving for a mean lean bowl of late night pho past the regular restaurant hours (My Canh is opened until 2AM) The pho was fulfilling. It hit every bone in my body that was calling for a pho craving. The broth had enough flavor and sustenance to keep my tummy warm and happy for the rest of the night. I wasn't too happy with the appearance of their bean sprouts. Some stems looked rather brown and sooty so I had to meticulously pick which lucky sprouts I wanted in my soup. 

It's hard to say if I would venture off to My Canh again. Although I was impressed with their extensive menu, tasty pho and accommodating hours, my germaphobic disposition can only endure so much smut in one sitting.
author: Ally C.

description:
My first pho experience.
Absolutely amazing. So much more satisfying than I thought a bowl of pho could ever be. Now that I live so close I'm sure I will frequent this place more often.
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
Tiny, ghetto, open late, delicious and cheap. What's not to love?

Banh canh cua: YUMMMMY! Perfect chewy noodles and delicious, flavorful broth with big crab claws in it!

Pho: Surprisingly really good too for a place that's supposed to specialize in banh canh, their pho is pretty up there with some of my favs!

Sidenote: Dirty = Authentic... Don't fear the grimy places!
author: Beverly T.

description: I can't really give this place a true rating only because every time I come here I'm drunk. Noodle soups are always a good way to sober up.  I ordered the Bun Rieu and I thought it was too oily and little flavor.  I heard there are a lot of good dishes but I can only give it a true rating if I come here sober. In other words, everyone who eats here after hours is drunk. So beware of belligerent people...and its a plus if you speak vietnamese.
author: Gina S.

description:
I got a bowl of bun ga nuong. 

It was pretty filling, and the five-spice chicken was nicely charred and seasoned, but the nuac mam for the bun was a bit too sweet. For $5.95, I ate to my fill, but I have definitely seen cleaner dining rooms and more pleasant service.

The hot tea served was lukewarm.
author: May T.

description: I always come here for their banh canh cua which like an udon like noodle seafood based soup. They are open late and wait for food isnt too bad. 3 stars because quality of food and service isn't as good as before and place is a bit on the dirty side
author: Melissa T.

description:
I want to slap people who complain about the following:

1) Cleanliness - Hippies, hipsters, and idiots usually complain about these things
2) Rudeness - Again, hipsters and hippies who think they own the world
3) Cash-only - Same crowd, usually people who know nothing about Chinatown, its history, or its residents

I'm really bitter as you can tell.  Seems to me that certain people are expecting certain businesses to cater to them.  The more gentrified Chinatown gets, the more upsetting it becomes.  Chinatown has been run a certain way for a long time and for certain reasons.  Stop trying to change the people who have been living there and doing things their way for years.  If you can't get over it, then please go somewhere else.

But this is a food review!  All I can say is get the "Vietnamese Crab Noodle Soup."  They will usually ask you "shell or no shell."  It's a personal preference.

Imagine if you were to get a foot massage, a back rub, psychological therapy, a makeover, all while in a sauna.  That's what it's like eating a bowl of crab noodle on a cold day.  

I honestly haven't tried anything else at this restaurant, nor do I care to.  But this one dish is what sets it apart from other restaurants in the area.  Try it.  I guarantee you'll walk away feeling good.

Just be aware, that it's not clean, it's not nice, and you gotta pay cash.  And it's not going to change.
author: SAS Z.

description:
Good Pho during sick and cold weather comfy food.
Good rice plate korean ribs & Fresh Squeeze Lemonade .
Reasonable Price.

Down Side is Cash Only but Atms are near by
author: Gruber T.

description: Had pho late at night. Tasted great, I was drunk and liked it a lot. Cleared my Sinuses too. Awesome. A+
author: Try E.

description:
BANH CANH CUA is the bomb! Period.
-Best ever- Large bowl of real crab pieces chopped up in the soup and perfect soup consistency...

Hole-in-the-Wall Opens past 3am.  Came here after a club and this place is packed with friends huddled together enjoying a nice bowl of "Souper San Fran Soup."

Authentic Chinese-Vietnamese food in the heart of SF does not get any better than this!

I wish we had this in the OC, even my brother still fantasizes about it...
author: Feel ..

description:
to me... the best banh canh cua (when you are tipsy) or not..
and may I add far better than most places on the beef carpaccio.... yummy.  bo tai chun
author: LENA D.

description: Worst pho in town. Clean bathroom.
author: Inigo M.

description:
spring rolls were pretty good~

The bun rieu was tastey..not the noodles we wanted but it was still good.

the porkchop over rice with shredded pork topped with a fried egg was good too.

And I enjoyed the coffee

service was quick and nice...server had smiles...

jus a bit too many flies taht day...

I kind of prefer Pho Hoa Hiep in DC over this place..but its a good restarurant and from the looks of it they open pretty late so thats also a bonus.
author: phillip w.

description:
The place is small, dirty and the bathroom is something from a horror movie, but this is probably the best hole in the wall in San Francisco. 

For about two years now I've been going to My Cahn, I order the same thing every time. Pho Tai, Lemon juice and Rare Beef with no peanuts, and every time I go there he brings me peanuts in my rare beef. Because the waiter is so friendly and the food is good, I shrug it off and don't point it out. The rare beef is not on the menu, so you have to ask for it by name. I used to come here with an ex who would order everything in Chinese, which is a disadvantage if you're planning on ordering from the 'secret menu' and don't speak their native tongue or able to just point to pictures. When I go there and ask for 'rare beef' for some reason they never seem to understand what I'm talking about and have to repeat myself while using hand gestures to finally get my order through. Keep trying, don't give up it only takes me a couple minutes of frustration eventually they'll get it.  

They're open until 4am so this place is awesome for late night cravings especially with a belly full of alcohol. It usually gets crowded after 2 am when the clubs close, but the service is so fast that I've never had to wait for a table despite the place being so small. The food is great and the portions are the perfect size.
author: Nalipay M.

description:
Good pho ga is hard to find after midnight!

Having the flu means my appetite comes on strong at inconvenient times and I was so thankful this place serves the antidote into the wee hours.  So it's a little dirty and worn, I don't care.  The servers are sweet and prompt, don't laugh at my botched Vietnamese and even checked to see how we were doing during our meal... this alone bumped them up a star because dammit I need my extra limes at some point and I don't like having to flag someone down to get them.  The chicken was good quality and the broth was tangy and light with beansprouts already added (less work for me!) no basil (that's ok -- see my Tu Lan review for theory on pho ga and basil) all topped with heaps of crispy fried garlic / shallot.  The garlic and two types of hot sauce available on the table were just the medicine I needed.  

We also orderd the banh xeo, which was on the thick and heavy side, but very satisfying as in you could actually taste the coconut milk in the mix, and served proper with heaps of fresh romaine lettuce, mint and an herb I do not know by name yet, the leaves of which resemble tiny eucalyptus (herb lovers throw me a bone here)...?

3.5 hot cocks rounded up to 4, because I care.
author: Molasses C.

description: We didn't get to eat here, but we stopped by and asked if we could use the bathroom. They were awesome enough to let us use it. As everyone in our group use the restroom, a few of us ordered fresh coconuts and grass jelly drinks before heading out on our food adventure. 5 stars for being nice while other shops would have been totally rude. We would stop here again and order food next time.
author: Anne T.

description:
Yummy! Looks totally ghetto and dirty inside, a block away from all the strip clubs, but don't judge a book by its cover! I'm not a fan of their banh canh, but mostly because I don't like that dish in general. However, you should give their raw beef salad a try. I actually thought their raw beef salad was better than the one I had at Pagolac. Portion sizes are generous and give their banh xeo a try. Hate the location because of the parking, but I'll be coming back because it's a good bang for your buck.

Make sure you bring cash!
author: Angela L.

description:
It was a late night on Broadway...i was feeling down....needed something to warm up my soul.

Checked this place out for the first time...had the Chicken Pho.

Pretty good and pretty standard. Little on the salty side but that's OK.

Maybe I'll try some other stuff on the menu next time.
author: Mario W.

description: It was alright although the noodles for the pho seemed clumped together as if it wasn't fully cooked. I liked how they had a "no grease" sign by the kitchen though which was true. No grease tasted at all with the pho. Just wish I could've taken a pic of that funny sign with my camera phone.
author: Gerard Y.

description:
I'm just not a pho person.

I finally tried it here - a place I see was just voted best pho in the city by SF Weekly - but I wasn't impressed.  i'm down to try it again, but this didn't give me a great first impression.

It's definitely a hole-in-the-wall type place.  And while I wouldn't mind seeing it cleaned up a bit, I know that's what adds to the charm of this place. 

I got the pho tai.  I wanted to like it, but I realized I'm not much for soupy-based meals, aside from a few exceptions.  The meat cuts were the best part. I thought the noodles were kinda bland. The broth was alright. The hot tea wasn't served so hot.

Service was adequate, prices were low.   This place is open late, so it's another late-night option.

My two pho-natical friends dug this place, so I think if you're really into pho, you will too.
author: Charles R.

description: bo tai chanh ( beef salad ) yeah
author: Bill J.

description:
i would take off a star for the appearance of the place, but that wouldn't be fair, really.

i came here on a random weekday night because i never had bo tai chanh before, AND everyone kept telling me to try their banh canh cua. i had to give in. yep, my friends and i drove an hour on a chilly night to have some of the goodness.

we were the only group of customers in the store and the waitress lady was really nice to us, probably because we were vietnamese haha. i tried bo tai chanh for the FIRST time, and i am DEATLHY afraid of raw meat products, even sashimi. the dish seriously looks scary, but my 3 friends dug right in and nudged me to just eat it. i did- and it was one of the best decisions i've ever made in my life! you just grab all of the meaty, lemony, oniony goodness, throw it in your mouth, and enjoy. i think i ate the most of the bo tai chanh out of the 3 of us, and i was afraid of it 5 minutes prior to eating it.

i didn't wanna spoil myself so i didn't eat TOO much of it, we all still had our banh canh cua to enjoy as well. so then it comes out- steaming hot, perfect for the cold sf weather. we asked for the crab claws to be taken out prior to being served, because it's quite a b_tch to grab the meat out with your hands in the hot steaming soup.

the banh canh cua was kinda thick- but not in a bad way, more of a hardy way. make sure to add them fried onion! i slurped up my whole bowl. i loved it.

i highly, highly recommend this hole-in-the-wall whenever you're in sf!
author: Danny P.

description: If I was to choose my last meal and if some how both Bun Bo Hue An Nam's in SJ got bombed, I would ask for Bun Bo Hue from this place. This place opens til the 2am, so if the club/bar was whack, you're hungry, and didn't want Sam Wo, check out this hole in the wall!
author: Wendy L.

description: came here with my sister for lunch after we went look for chinese new year clothing for the kids. it was yum yum! but i wish i could eat seafood, cause my sisters crab noodle looks amazing!
author: Winnie C.

description:
When you walk down the block from after drinking, and your foot goes in front of the other and you stumble, its always good to be able to stumble into this fine establishment late at night.  On a normal basis, i'd probably give this place a 3 but then for opening late at night and accomodating the drunk people that like to come to good o chinatown for after drinkin food, that's a well deserved extra star.  

My friend had a #28 bowl of pho, but it looked kinda wack.  I had the house special ho fun and it was pretty good actually.  It had a single scallop, some cuttlefish, brocolli, and some other stuff i forget.  It was actually good because the noodles weren't flaky or overcooked.  Lots of places tend to not cook them enough and they end up hardening up and breaking.  Definitely a good spot to go.  $13 for 2 people.  good huh?
author: Vincent K.

description:
This place really does deserve 4.5 stars.

Most people who write their reviews about this place comment on being intoxicated and as a result, famished, hungry, and desperate for nutrition. 

I came here with my gf for lunch, both sober. I decided it would be the best way to review this place since it'd be on a different level. But I must side with all the people on here, This place is really good!

We tried the Bo Tai Chanh which was around $12.95 or so but very worth it. The beef is served raw, smothered in lime juice, cilantro, chopped peanuts, some chili, fried garlic and fish sauce. To many of you who may be discouraged by eating raw beef for fear of contamination, let it be known that e. coli lives in the intestines of the cow as well as yourself. Hamburger is where you would find traces of e.coli if any due to the fact that hamburger is pretty much different parts of the cow ground together. But the beef here is I think flank steak, sliced wafer thin. The acidity of the lime juice does its job to not only tenderize the meat even more but kill of trace bacteria. Chemistry and biology lesson aside, the beef was melt in your mouth tender and the combination of the add-ons just made the whole dish savory and delish. 

We also got the banh xeo, which had a few pieces of shrimp, lots of bean sprouts, a few pieces of bacon all wrapped in a pancake/crepe batter. You can taste the coconut milk in the batter, and all in all it was pretty good but not anything super exciting. 

Banh Canh Cua was great! The soup comes nicely thickened from boiling the banh canh noodles in the broth. I think Banh Canh is made from tapioca flour so it naturally thickened up the flavorful broth. We asked them to shell the crab meat for us and there were about 3 crab legs worth of meat as well as a claw. There were also pieces of pork hock and the curdled pigs blood. Very good! Noodles were chewy and springy and I really liked the broth. A few squirts of Sriracha and I knew that this bowl of noodles would cure any hangover.
author: Derrick L.

description:
This place is great for post-drinking, post-clubbing, post-strip club (not that I would know, but there are quite a few clubs in the area)...it's open every day until 2a!  I've been here three times for dinner, but have never remembered to get a takeout menu until today when I looked at an apartment in the area.  (It's taken me this long to yelp it because I could never remember the name of the restaurant, or how to spell "banh cahn.")  The area looks completely different during the day...sooooo much seedier when the sun goes down.

When I go, I always get the banh canh cua (#21)...apparently this is THE place to get it - it's quite the destination when we're here from Vallejo.  The broth is nice and thick, noodles are good, crab meat is yummy, and the blood cake...wait.  Okay, I made myself try it once, but since then, I either set it aside or give it away.  It doesn't take anything away from the food though, and I'm sure enhances it if you're into that sort of thing.

The place is a hole in the wall...just as it should be.  Yum.
author: Kerrie L.

description:
This small place is definitely hole in the wall and dingy but it's open late to satisfy the drunken munchies after the bars and clubs close at 2am and it's a good alternative to Denny's or Mel's so that gets 4 stars alone.

Honestly, I've only eaten here after a night of drinking so I really don't remember what I've ordered but it's always been soup. Various types of noodle soup with the fixings, blood cubes and all. Delicious, soothing noodle soup really makes me feel better when I feel like the alcohol is getting to me...except this one time a few years ago when I threw up in their bathroom (woops).
author: kristin e.

description:
In Vietnam, I ate a lot of pho. The best pho always seemed to be served by sort of sketchy-looking joints in back alleys or little stands squeezed between shops selling a mishmash of other stuff. My little hotel in Hanoi made a pretty good western style breakfast, but if I ordered pho instead, they would send a guy from the kitchen down the street to one of these places. He'd walk back in through the front door of the hotel, and put the outsourced pho down on my table.

When I find myself near Broadway and Columbus in San Francisco, and I'm not down with Dim Sum or Italian food, a steaming bowl of pho at My Canh is a good option. When you walk into a Vietnamese restaurant, and it's full of Vietnamese people, you've probably made a good choice. Certainly true with regard to My Canh anyway.

Pho is one of those things - like pizza - that I could happily eat three times a day for the next ten years, and you can get it delicious and cheap at My Canh.
author: Shawn S.

description:
So I eat here by myself... a lot. Why? I can never convince anyone else that this place is worth a shot because, frankly, it's scary for most. When I first moved to SF, this place was quickly deemed a health hazard by my friends. Almost 5 years later, I'm still kicking and going back to this staple Broadway joint because, damn it, it's good. First off, Americans are spoiled whiny people. Grow up in Asia or anywhere else, and you'll know what I'm talking about. I mean, who cares if the pork chop you just ordered is caught in transit to the kitchen via a sliding bucket on the floor being kicked by a 4 foot tall Asian granny? It's going to be fried to oblivion so I'm sure all possible contagions are long gone by the time it ends up in your mouth. 

Anyway, my go to dish is the BBQ pork over rice WITH a fried egg (always got to keep it true to my roots and channel Filipino food combinations). It's hearty and just good. The vermicelli bowls are also great and the fried imperial rolls are the sh*t. I'm not a pho fan so no comment on that. The place is also open until 4am so it's a very valid option to other late night joints in the area.
author: Jonny Bobby G.

description:
YUM! My Canh has by far the best bo tai chanh (raw beef salad). I can eat 1 3/4 of an order or maybe more. It has the right amount of everything in it. Great service too. Usually there is a long wait to eat after 1am but homegirl that works there always hooks us up. 

The banh canh cua (crab soup) is also very tasty. You get a lot of soup, noodles, pork blood chunks, and enough crab. They even peel it for you if you ask with no $2 fee.

It's also a great place to run into a lot of friends after the bar or club. Usually people are buzzed and hugging each other and sharing food.

Mmmm makes me wanna grab a drink tonight so that I can eat there afterwards.
author: Stephanie P.

description: This place is a wreck but it was the only thing open after I left a concert... The entire restaurant in general is FILTHY!! I mean everything - the bathroom, the walls, and the tables... I was seriously looking on the floor for rodents... One star for being open late & another Star for being prompt quick with our food.
author: LuLu G.

description:
tasty pho...with larger than life tasty egg rolls and spring rolls....you get your hoisin and rooster sauce....with bountiful sprouts, limes, jalepenos and mint leaves.....

the negative....i complained that my extra large pho was smaller than the regular pho...(even the bowl was smaller)...the waitress seems friendly with a smile...but she won't listen and just passes by....oh well...still was tasty pho....this is another one of those "dive" restaurants in chinatown...not much ventilation and flies buzzing around...
author: Hen A.

description:
service was prompt and friendly. 

we came back here for our late night NYE dinner after the fireworks. the place was packed and we had to wait in a line outside the door for a good 10 minutes. the wait was worth it.

we had "banh canh cua" which was crab in thick rice/tapioca noodles in thick, hearty soup. i don't remember for sure, but i think it's #16 on the menu.
